Afternoon: Post Office Bay and Baroness Viewpoint (Floreana) In the 18th century, the crew of a whaling ship placed a wooden barrel at Post Office Bay. Letters put inside were collected and delivered by sailors returning home. There was no postage fee and, surprisingly, this mailbox honour system is still in use today. Although letters are no longer from sailors to their loved ones, tourists leave thousands of them today and many still reach their destination. You can also relax on the beach, where, in addition to Galapagos sea lions, Pacific green turtles and golden rays, you may see Galapagos penguins. This is the only place in the southeastern archipelago where penguins reside. You can also climb the small basaltic cone of Baroness Lookout and enjoy the paradisiacal coastline views. This viewpoint was the favourite spot of one of Floreana's first settlers, the eccentric baroness and self-proclaimed Empress of the Galapagos, Eloisa von Wagner, who even built her house a few metres further back. There will be a long navigation at the end of the day, so we recommend you take medication for seasickness. Accommodation: Solaris

Morning: Sullivan Bay (Santiago) The arrival in Sullivan Bay is like a moon landing. The desolate, sprawling fields seem to be mostly lifeless; but this island, which is particularly popular among photographers, still has a lot to offer. Green sea turtles burrow in the small white-sand beach, where you can also find crabs, blue herons and oystercatchers. Afternoon: Bartolomé The beautiful volcanic islet of Bartolomé is among the youngest of the islands and, on a geological scale, was just recently born out of the fire. Although it looks lifeless at first sight, Bartolomé has some of the wildest landscapes and best panoramas in the entire archipelago. To enjoy an idyllic view of Pinnacle Bay, climb the stairs to the viewpoint on top of the island (375ft/114m). You enter a dramatic world of (extinguished) spatter cones, craters, and lightweight lava droplets once spewed out by fiery fountains. The summit trail is also ideal for witnessing how pioneer vegetation, such as lava cactus, struggles to take root in the bare virgin lava fields. Accommodation: Solaris

Morning: Black Turtle Cove (Santa Cruz) This small bay, on the north side of Santa Cruz, offers a unique backdrop for unique adventures. The landscape makes you feel as if you're in the Amazon rainforest rather than near the sea. Explore the quiet emerald lagoon and surrounding shallow bays with the inflatable dinghy. The crystal-clear water allows you to spot groups of whitetip reef sharks, blacktip reef sharks, hammerhead sharks, gold rays, and spotted eagle rays. Afternoon: transfer to Baltra Airport Finishing our activities around 9am, the dinghy takes us (and our luggage) to Baltra, where we take the airport shuttle for our flight to Guayaquil, which typically departs around 11.38am. Arriving, you can catch your international flights from 6pm onwards.

placesVisited: San Cristobal island, Kicker Rock dive, Santa Cruz island, Puerto Ayora dive sites, Sightseeing
generalInfo:
This is a fantastic holiday with an active, week long programme, staying in comfortable hotels on two of the Galapagos islands. To participate in this tour you need to have a valid PADI certificate.

The tour begins on San Cristobal island, the easternmost of all the islands and location of the renowned landmark Kicker Rock, an impressive offshore rock formation. It attracts many of the islands feathered residents, from blue footed boobies to frigates, which roost in the walls and cracks of the rock. But it's what lies beneath the surface that makes this area so special; a naturally eroded channel provides the perfect home for sharks, rays and reef fish. Before going out on the boat, there will be some free time to visit some of the island's attractions.

On day three the tour moves on to Puerto Ayora, on Santa Cruz island. There is a plethora of excellent dive sites within reach of the town, and we will spend the remainder of the holiday exploring some of them. Site and conditions depending, you will be be able to enjoy two immersions and a dive check each day. Some of the marine life to watch out for includes manta rays, barracudas, hammerhead sharks and seahorses, as well as playful sea lions and graceful sea turtles. When you're not in the water, there will time for some sightseeing, and you can choose to visit the Charles Darwin station, Tortuga Bay, the Santa Cruz highlands, or wherever interests you most.

dayInfo.description: SAN CRISTOBAL - FREE TIME Upon arrival to Galapagos (San Cristobal Airport) our transportation will take you to the village (5 minutes). You can check in to the hotel and you can visit some nice places by yourself (Playa Mann, Tijeretas etc). We provide you a self-guided package for the best tips and restaurants. Around 17.00 you should visit the dive school to prepare for your first dive the next day. Accommodation in Hotel Casa Opuntia or similar

DIVING KICKER ROCK (B, L) Today you will go on your first dive in the Galapagos islands! You will go for about 45 minutes by boat to reach Kicker Rock. When you get there you will have a short check dive to make sure your equipment is good. After this you do two immersions of about 50 minutes each. After the dives you have a lunch on board and whenever the current is good and the National Park has given the permission you will visit a beach close by to relax. Around 3 – 4 PM you will be back in the village. Accommodation in Hotel Casa Opuntia or similar

FREE TIME SAN CRISTOBAL – SANTA CRUZ SPEEDBOAT (B) In the morning you have to visit some spots by yourself; for example the Loberia or Playa Chino. At 2 PM you will take the public speedboat to get to Santa Cruz island (Puerto Ayora village). The boat ride takes about 2,5 hours. Upon arrival you should visit the dive school to try out your gear. At night you can walk around in the cosy village and try one of the (seafood) restaurants. Accommodation in Hotel Fiesta or similar.

DIVING FROM PUERTO AYORA 1 (B, L) After breakfast the dive guide will take you to one of the dive sites around Santa Cruz. As mentioned before, where you go depends on the day of the week. You will reach the dive sites by speedboat. Depending on the dive site, this ride will take you between 30 minutes and 2,5 hours. You will have a check dive and two immersions from about 50 minutes each. The maximum depth for this dive site is 30m. You do need a PADI degree. Depending on the site you will be back in the village between 3 – 6 PM so in the afternoon you have time to visit the Charles Darwin station, Tortuga Bay, Santa Cruz highlands, Las Grietas or Playa de los Alemanes by yourself. Accommodation in Hotel Fiesta or similar

DIVING FROM PUERTO AYORA 2 (B, L) After breakfast the dive guide will take you to one of the dive sites around Santa Cruz. As mentioned before, where you go depends on the day of the week. You will reach the dive sites by speedboat. Depending on the dive site, this ride will take you between 30 minutes and 2,5 hours. You will have a check dive and two immersions from about 50 minutes each. The maximum depth for this dive site is 30m. Accommodation in Hotel Fiesta or similar

DIVING FROM PUERTO AYORA 3 (B, L) After breakfast the dive guide will take you to one of the dive sites around Santa Cruz. As mentioned before, where you go depends on the day of the week. You will reach the dive sites by speedboat. Depending on the dive site, this ride will take you between 30 minutes and 2,5 hours. You will have a check dive and two immersions from about 50 minutes each. The maximum depth for this dive site is 30m. Accommodation in Hotel Fiesta or similar
TRANSFER OUT (B) Today your Galapagos Diving trip end. You can choose a flight out from Baltra at any hour, the drop off will be planned about 3,5 hours before your departure. End of services

placesVisited: Quito, San Cristobal, Las Tijeteras, Manglaralto Beach, Kicker Rock, San Cristobal highlands, Isla Floreana, Tortuga Island, Sierra Negra Volcano, Volcan Azufre, Puerto Villamil, Galapagos giant tortoise breeding centre, Santa Cruz, Tortuga Bay, possibility of also visiting Bartolome Island, South Plaza Island or North Seymour
generalInfo:
This two week small group trekking holiday in the Galapagos Islands takes place across the archipelago to leave travellers in no uncertain terms as to the rugged natural beauty of offshore Ecuador as well as the abundance of animals, both on land and in the ocean, indigenous to the islands.

One of many highlights of this holiday includes a 10km trek around the rim of the Sierra Negra crater on Isabela Island where the stunning views from the top of the volcano are matched only by the unique excitement of walking in the realm of steaming fumaroles and solidified lava fields.

From giant tortoises to an inordinate amount of birdlife, Isabela is an incredible island to explore on two feet and as this 15 day tour also includes treks on Santa Cruz, San Cristobal and visits to Florena, you’ll be able to compare and contrast remote regions of the Galapagos as part of a uniquely inspiring walking experience.

dayInfo.description: Begin the adventure in Quito, Ecuador’s capital, high in the Andes. To make things easy, there are free transfers from the airport to the hotel for everyone today – check the Joining Instructions for further details. Around 6pm, say hola to your Quito tour leader and fellow travellers, when we gather as a group for the first time to get to know each other and learn more about the adventures ahead. Want more time in Quito? Secure pre-tour hotel nights through your sales representative. Accommodation: Hotel Vieja Cuba (or similar) Upgrade to a suite today – speak to your sales representative for more details

This morning, we take a guided tour of the Old Town. Quito is the second-highest capital in the world, standing at 9,350ft (2,850m) on the western cordillera of the Andes. It is one of the smaller and more attractive of the colonial capitals in South America. Due to the altitude, you are advised to take it easy at first and drink plenty of water. After, you may wish to join an optional excursion to the equator, which is just 40 minutes’ drive north of Quito. Here, you visit the fun – and interactive – Intiñan Equator Museum, which explores indigenous culture and traditions, as well as unique phenomena related to the geographic location. Your tour leader ensures a big Ecuadorian welcome by arranging a group dinner tonight. Accommodation: Hotel Vieja Cuba (or similar) Upgrade to a suite today – speak to your sales representative for more details

Rise early (leaving the hotel around 5am with a box breakfast) as we transfer to Quito Airport for our flight to San Cristóbal in the Galapagos via Guayaquil. Your Galapagos tour leader (an official naturalist guide) takes you from the airport to the hotel for check-in and our first briefing about our time in the archipelago. We have time to explore the town and enjoy a restaurant lunch, before picking up our snorkelling equipment and, if you’d like, renting wetsuits. After this, we visit to La Lobería, a wonderful beach surrounded by mangroves, volcanic rocks and sea lion colonies. It’s a perfect spot to snorkel, relax on the sands, or have a short walk along the shore. Accommodation: Hotel Paraiso Insular (or similar)

Travel (40 minutes) by small motorboat to León Dormido (also known as Kicker Rock), an impressive lava tuff formation. Several species of nesting seabirds reside here, including masked boobies. We can snorkel and, with any luck, spot eagle rays, Galapagos turtles, hammerhead sharks and a great variety of fish. Continue by boat, enjoying lunch en route, to one of three white-sand beaches for a walk: Playa Ochoa, Playa Manglecito or Cerro Brujo. Playa Ochoa is an expanse of white sand dominated by a large sea lion colony and is home to many birds and marine iguanas. Playa Manglecito offers both the opportunity to visit a white-sand beach and a mangrove area. Cerro Brujo is in a volcanic zone, has abundant vegetation and is home to sea lions, marine iguanas and many birds. Accommodation: Hotel Paraiso Insular (or similar)

Drive to the San Cristóbal highlands after breakfast. A one-hour walk brings us to the fringe of El Junco Lake, one of the few permanent freshwater lakes in the Galapagos, where frigatebirds often bathe nearby. The highlands offer panoramic views across the smaller islands lapped by the Pacific. After, we visit a reserve where Galapagos giant tortoises roam free. After lunch at a local restaurant, we can visit La Loberia, a sea lion nursery, the perfect place to unwind and snorkel, surrounded by sea lions and marine iguanas. Accommodation: Hotel Paraiso Insular (or similar)

A three-hour navigation by motorboat takes us to Floreana, one of the first islands to be inhabited in the Galapagos, yet still relatively untouched by development – don’t expect to see many restaurants or shops! En route, we may see whales, dolphins and sea birds. After lunch at one of the few local restaurants, we visit the highlands and see lava caves once used by pirates and a large enclosure of Galapagos giant tortoises. Accommodation: Lava Lodge (or similar)

After an early breakfast, we go on a walk to discover the black volcanic beaches, which are home to red iguanas and sea lion colonies. There is also time to snorkel this morning (please note, the visit to this beach might be done in the late afternoon on Day 6 on some departures). Just before midday, we navigate to Isabela. This afternoon, we walk (2.5mi/4km) to the Wall of Tears, a reminder of Isabela’s very different past when the island was used as a penal colony. Between 1946 and 1959, convicts were forced to build this wall from huge lava blocks simply as a form of punishment, which, combined with the harsh conditions, led to many deaths. After this sobering visit, we hike back to the town through mangroves, wetlands and along sandy beaches. This is one of the best places on the islands to view migratory birds, including Wilson’s phalaropes, blue-winged teals and, if we’re very lucky, ospreys. This region has also seen the reintroduction of Galapagos giant tortoises and we are likely to encounter several on our walk. Accommodation: San Vicente Hotel (or similar)

It’s our toughest hiking day, but one that’s worth the effort as we tackle trails on the active shield volcano of Sierra Negra. Our five to six-hour adventure takes us across stark, lava-strewn highlands punctuated by miconia shrubs and other vegetation. The otherworldly landscapes are incredible, and we pass many volcanic features along the way, where we can observe fumaroles and a variety of lava formations. To keep us fuelled, we’re provided with a box lunch. Accommodation: San Vicente Hotel (or similar)

We snorkel in the Cabo Rosa area today, among the best places in the Galapagos for a snorkel adventure. We start with a 30-minute walk around the tunnels formed here by volcanic activity, before getting into the water, where we have a chance to swim with sea turtles, manta rays, marine iguanas and even penguins. Lunch is served on board the boat. Accommodation: San Vicente Hotel (or similar)

Spend 15 minutes sailing to the islets and lava channels of Las Tintoreras, one of the best places in the Galapagos to see whitetip reef sharks, penguins and sea lions. A 40-minute walk takes us around the islet and back to the boat again, before we jump into the water for a snorkel! The afternoon is free for swimming, snorkelling, walking or just relaxing on one of the beaches around Puerto Villamil. Accommodation: San Vicente Hotel (or similar)

Following breakfast at our hotel, we navigate by motorboat (2hr 30min) to Santa Cruz. Arriving, we have the option of visiting the Charles Darwin Research Station, which is home to the headquarters of the Charles Darwin Foundation. This is the main research hub on the islands and scientists come from around the world to study the flora and fauna here. After our visit, we have lunch at a local restaurant. Our destination this afternoon is Tortuga Bay, a long stretch of white sand. The trail leading to the beach is paved and takes between 45 minutes and one hour, with the chance to see Galapagos finches and lizards. The beach itself is scattered with marine iguanas, who lay among the clusters of black rocks or stroll along the sand. In the water, turtles can sometimes be seen. Swimming is not recommended here due to strong currents. After a relaxing afternoon, we hike the same route back towards the main town of Puerto Ayora where our hotel is located. Accommodation: Mainao Hotel (or similar) Upgrade to a superior or a suite today – speak to your sales representative for more details

Visit either Bartolomé Island, South Plaza Island or North Seymour (depending on national park restrictions). South Plaza has a remarkable vegetation of succulents and cacti that provide a unique habitat for land iguanas. The iguanas form small colonies at the base of the tall opuntia cacti, waiting for their flowers and dead pads to fall to the ground so they can feed. The island rocks are home to swallowtail gulls, shearwaters and sea lions. North Seymour is a flat, boulder-strewn island and a major nesting site for frigatebirds. It’s also a good place to see blue-footed boobies performing courtship rituals and sea lions playing in the powerful surf. Bartolomé is a spectacular scene of dramatic lava cones, clear seas and affords perhaps the most famous view of the Galapagos Islands, looking across the red cinder cones to the recent black lava fields on James Island. If possible, we snorkel today where the water is calm, and enjoy lunch on the boat. Accommodation: Mainao Hotel (or similar) Upgrade to a superior or a suite today – speak to your sales representative for more details

After breakfast, we drive to Baltra airport, where we say a fond farewell to our Galapagos tour leader. Our flight via Guayaquil returns us to Quito, where we meet our Quito tour leader and spend our final evening together. Accommodation: Hotel Vieja Cuba (or similar) Upgrade to a suite today – speak to your sales representative for more details
Our adventure ends after breakfast, and we begin our return journeys home. If you’d like to continue your exploration of Quito with extra nights, speak to your sales representative.

tourName: Galapagos Islands land based holiday, 1 week
placesVisited: Santa Cruz Highlands, Charles Darwin Research Station, Uninhabited island tour, Isabela, Los Tuneles, Kayak in Tintoreras Bay, San Cristobal, Snorkel at Kicker Rock
generalInfo:
This small group Galapagos Islands tour takes you to all the best bits of the Galapagos in just one week. The Galapagos Islands was crowned Leading Beach Destination of 2018 at the World Travel Awards, and it’s easy to see why. You’ll visit stunning islands and beaches and experience the marine and land-based animals that have fascinated biologists and nature lovers since the days of Darwin, with opportunities to explore on two feet, two wheels and on the water all adding to the adventure.

Highlights of your journey will include kayaking in Tintoreras Bay, with the opportunity to see sharks; viewing giant Galapagos tortoises in the Santa Cruz Highlands and watching crowds of sea lions at San Cristobal Island.

All of our tour guides and local people who know and love their home environment and are eager to share that knowledge with you.

dayInfo.description: AIRPORT PICKUP – SANTA CRUZ HIGHLANDS – CHARLES DARWIN (L) Upon arrival at Baltra Airport the guide will take you to Santa Cruz Highlands to make closer contact with the Giant Galapagos Tortoises as well as many kinds of birds, like the Wizard and Finch. Here you’ll also visit the Charles Darwin Research Station. The guides will explain more about the famous giant tortoises and you will have a local lunch here. Then you will be taken to your hotel where you have some time to relax. Accommodation in Hotel Fiesta or similar.

LONG DAY TOUR – UNINHABITED ISLAND (B, BL) Continuing with your Hidden Treasures Galapagos tour, this day you will go to one of Galapagos’ uninhabited islands. Which island you will visit depends on what day of the week you will depart. Examples of islands you might visit are: Bartolomé, Santa Fe or Seymour. You will spend the day snorkeling and discovering the island and its flora and fauna. In the afternoon you will return to your hotel. Accommodation in Hotel Fiesta or similar

FREE MORNING – ISABELA ISLAND (B) After breakfast at the hotel, you have some time to discover the island by yourself. We highly recommend you to visit Tortuga Bay, where you will be able to spot a huge marine iguana colony. At 02.00 PM you will be brought to Isabela island by boat and you will arrive around 04.30 PM. After that you will be picked up and brought to your hotel. Accommodation in Hotel Volcano or similar

LOS TUNELES (B, S) Today you will go to Los Tuneles. This is one of the true Hidden Treasures of Galapagos and the most spectacular places to go diving or snorkeling in Isabela Island, because the water is calm, very clear and shallow. After visiting Los Tuneles you will have time to visit some highlights by yourself; for example to Isabela Breeding Center, Wetlands or the Wall of Tears. Accommodation in Hotel Volcano or similar

KAYAK IN TINTORERAS BAY – DROP OFF AIRPORT – SAN CRISTOBAL (B) Early in the morning you will have breakfast at the hotel. After that, you have the chance to do a kayaking or stand up paddling tour in Tintoreras Bay. When you finish relaxing on the water, you will be picked up to be brought to the Isabela Airport. From there you will take a flight to San Cristobal. Here you can visit the Interpretation Center and Tijeretas on your own. A great thing is that San Cristobal airport is situated very well so it only takes a couple of minutes to get from the airport to the hotel. Accommodation in Casa Opuntia or similar

KICKER ROCK (B, BL) You will have breakfast at the hotel before going to Kicker Rock. This is one of the most spectacular landmarks of the Galapagos Islands. Two volcanic rocks of 140 meters tall, located off the coast of San Cristobal Island. In the sea you see the great underwater life wherefore the site is that famous. The natural erosion of this ancient cone has created a channel between the rocks that provides the ideal habitat to view a variety of sharks and rays including eagle rays, white-tip reef sharks, and sometimes even the Galapagos sharks and hammerheads! Accommodation in Casa Opuntia or similar

TRANSFER OUT (B) This is the last day of your Hidden Treasures Galapagos tour. Depending on the time of your flight back to the mainland, you will be brought to the airport. Any time of the day is fine to get your flight out, we will arrange a transfer to the airport for you. End of Services.

generalInfo: This 5 day Galapagos Multisport tour is full of sports activities like kayak, snorkeling, mountain biking, and hiking. You will stay 4 nights on the biggest island of the Galapagos; Isabela island. While doing the activities you will observe plenty of wildlife: playful sea lions, giant manta rays, colorful fish and, giant Galapagos tortoises.  Enjoy a Galapagos Multisport Adventure!

dayInfo.description: Today is the first day of your Galapagos Multisport tour. It will be necessary for you to book flights with an early arrival time to Baltra Airport to make sure you can enjoy all of the activities of the program. At Baltra Airport, your English speaking guide will pick you up and take you to the port of Puerto Ayora where you can enjoy your lunch. Around 02:00 PM, you will take a small public speedboat to Isabela Island. This can be a bumpy, wet ride so we recommend bringing a waterproof jacket and motion sickness medication, if necessary. Upon arrival to Isabela Island, a driver will pick you up, and then you will visit the Flamingo Lagoon. After that, you will be dropped off at your hotel.

Early in the morning, after breakfast, you will take an excursion to the Sierra Negra Volcano. This volcano is located 13 miles from Puerto Villamil, and has the second largest volcanic crater in the world. To arrive at this incredible sight, you will travel by bus for 45 minutes. Once there, you will begin the hike to the Sierra Negra Volcano. A box lunch will be served at the volcano. After a somewhat challenging hike, you will return to the hotel where you cant have a brief rest. Next, you will have the chance to go snorkeling or swimming at Concha Perla, where you can observe colorful fish, sea lions, and other marine species, even a sea turtle.

After breakfast, you will be picked up from your hotel, and you will get on the bike to go visit the Giant Tortoise Breeding Center and the Wall of Tears. From 1946 to 1959 Isabela was designated a penal colony by the Ecuadorian government. Prisoners were forced to build a wall with huge lava rocks, which is why it is called now Wall of Tears. After this, you will return to the hotel for lunch. In the afternoon, you will sail to Tintoreras Islet. It is called this way because of the white-tip sharks that inhabit the islet, which is known as Tintoreras. Here, you can also observe penguins, sea lions, and marine iguanas, and you can go snorkeling with sharks and a variety of multicolored fish.

Today, you will head to the bay of Puerto Villamil together with your guide. Here, you will go kayaking and visit the coastal zone. You will have the opportunity to observe and photograph marine iguanas, sea lions, penguins, and more. Then, after a short break, you will return to the hotel for lunch. In the afternoon, you will get on your bike again, and go to the top of Isabela Island to visit Cave Sucre, the Mango viewpoint, and Campo Duro. Here, you can see and approach the giant tortoises in their natural habitat.

Today, your Galapagos Multisport adventure comes to an end. Early in the morning, you will travel to Santa Cruz Island on the public speedboat. You will get a packed breakfast to enjoy on the way. Upon arrival in Puerto Ayora, your Spanish-speaking driver will bring you to Baltra Airport.

tourName: Galapagos Islands small ship cruise holiday
generalInfo:
This wonderful 10 day sailing adventure through the north, central and south islands of the incredible Galapagos islands will see you travel in style aboard the small yacht "Eden" to discover some of the Galápagos' most unique species and spectacular sights. With 7 nights on board, included internal flights and a night in historic Quito both before and after your sail, this is the ideal itinerary for exploring this remarkable part of the world. Enjoy included excursions, hikes and snorkelling as you see for yourself why the Galapagos Islands are known as “Mother Nature’s Zoo”.

- Sail aboard a comfortable small vessel which holds a maximum of 16 guests
- Visit exceptionally scenic islands including Genovesa, Bartolomé, Floreana and San Cristóbal
- Search for a huge variety of wildlife sightings such as giant tortoises, marine iguanas and an abundance of birds including the famous red and blue-footed boobies
- Enjoy included snorkelling excursions and hikes

Various dates available

dayInfo.description: Quito: Arrive independently to Quito and take your transfer to the hotel for your included overnight stay. Depending on your arrival time you may have time to explore some of this fascinating and historic city set high in the Andean foothills that is a designated UNESCO World Heritage Site. In the evening your tour representative will meet you at the hotel for a briefing on what lies ahead and what to expect from your exciting Galapagos cruise.

Quito to The Galapagos: After breakfast this morning your transfer will take you to the airport for your included flight to the Galapagos Islands. Upon arrival in Baltra we will transfer to the shore to board the Eden and enjoy our first lunch onboard. After settling in to your comfortable cabin we will head out on our first excursion which will take us to Bachas Beach. On Bachas Beach the sand is made of decomposed coral, making it soft and white, and a favourite site for nesting sea turtles. We will hope for our first sightings of sea turtles here, but it’s not only the turtles that we’ll be on the lookout for. Sally Lightfoot crabs on the lava rocks along the water's edge, flamingos, marine iguanas and black necked stilts are just a few of the species we are likely to see on this first stop…the perfect introduction to the Galapagos!

Genovesa Island: Our first full day in the Galapagos Islands will see us visit Darwin Bay on Genovesa Island where you can enjoy a lovely walk along the coral sands surrounded by an abundance of seabirds, or take a snorkelling excursion to a sunken caldera to see large schools of tropical fish, and if lucky, some sea lions, hammerhead sharks, white-spotted eagle rays and manta rays. In the afternoon you will visit El Barranco for a fabulous wildlife experience. Also known as “Prince Phillip's Steps”, you can climb the steps to see a huge seabird colony where you will find the breeding grounds for masked, blue-footed and red-footed boobies.

Bartolomé Island / Sullivan Bay: This morning we will visit Bartolomé Island to enjoy a guided tour around the island's dramatic volcanic features, a hike to the summit for spectacular views of Pinnacle Rock, the island’s famous landmark, and an optional snorkel along the island’s iconic volcanic rock formations. While we’re here we’ll also hope for sightings of the island’s Galápagos penguin colony, as well as sea lions and sea turtles. In the afternoon we will sail on to Sullivan Bay on Santiago Island to see and walk along its fascinating giant lava formations and stark landscapes.

Black Turtle Cove / Cerro Dragón: This morning you’ll take a panga (small boat) ride to Black Turtle Cove to explore through the mangroves and see a variety of marine wildlife in both the salt and fresh waters of the area, keeping a keen eye out in particular for the Whitetip reef sharks and sting rays that are often found here. Later in the afternoon, a trip to Cerro Dragón will allow you to enjoy a short walk through a Palo Santo tree forest to the see the Scalesia trees that are endemic to the area and visit the hypersalinic (saltier than the ocean) lagoon to see flamingos and a wide variety of other birds.

Puerto Ayora: Today brings us to Puerto Ayora on Santa Cruz Island where you can visit Fausto Llerena Breeding Center and Charles Darwin Research Station. Here we will learn all about the ongoing conservation efforts on the islands and see several subspecies of adult and hatchling tortoises, including seeing the famous Galapagos tortoise up-close, learning about how these programs are helping them to avoid extinction. You can also enjoy a trip into Santa Cruz’s verdant highlands to see these giant reptiles, the Galapagos’ most famous residents, in their natural habitat, before some free time to explore around Puerto Ayora at your leisure.

Floreana Island / Punta Cormorant: On day 7 we will reach Floreana Island where we will make land at Post Office Bay to learn all about its unique history and abundant wildlife and birdlife. The tradition here is to drop off a letter at the barrel that was left by whalers in the 18th century and take one with you that you could deliver to its final destination. In Punta Cormorant you can visit two dramatically different beaches: one with green sand, coloured by olivine crystals, and another with white sand particles known as 'Flour Beach, before making your way to the nearby lagoon to see penguins, flamingos and marine iguanas. You could also opt for another fantastic snorkelling experience at an old underwater volcanic cone known as the “Devil’s Crown” and renowned for its strong currents.

Española Island: Today you can enjoy a full day on Española Island, one of the oldest islands in the Galapagos archipelago. A visit to Punta Suarez, which is one of most wildlife-rich landing sites in the Galápagos, should reward in sightings of sea lions, waved albatross and much more. On the white sandy beaches and turquoise waters of Gardner Bay you may also spot red-billed tropic birds, hood mockingbirds, lava lizards, Galapagos hawks and Nazca and blue-footed boobies…to name just a few!

San Cristóbal Island & Back to Quito: Our last stop will take us to San Cristóbal Island where you can visit the Interpretation Centre for some more history lessons on the Galapagos, from their volcanic origins to the conservation efforts in place in the modern day. The Human History exhibit is definitely worth a visit before it’s time to catch the flight back to Quito, where upon arrival you will be transferred to your hotel for your included overnight stay. On the morning of day 10 it will be time to check out as your itinerary sadly comes to an end. There are various opportunities for extending your stay in Quito including city tours and volcano tours so please enquire for details if you wish to add on even more adventure.

generalInfo:
Embark on the adventure of a lifetime with this Galapagos Islands swimming tour. This unique journey offers an unparalleled opportunity to explore one of the most biodiverse and pristine ecosystems on the planet.

Swim through crystal-clear waters, surrounded by vibrant marine life, and experience the thrill of swimming with sea lions, turtles, and an array of tropical fish.

Whether you're an experienced swimmer or a beginner, our expert guides will ensure a safe and memorable experience. Sail into the heart of the Galapagos and discover the beauty of its underwater world like never before.

Join us for an extraordinary aquatic adventure!

dayInfo.description: Tonight you will stay at the Sheraton Quito meeting at 6pm for a welcome drink and dinner.
Morning | We will take a flight to San Cristobel in the Galapagos Afternoon | La Loberia swim with large Galapagos sea lions.
Morning | Coastal swim at Punta Suarez, Española Island Afternoon | North coastline swim, with the possibility of spotting blue sharks, zayapas & sea turtles.
Morning | Transfer to the liveaboard and set sail Afternoon | Lobos Island Channel Swim
Morning | Pitch Point Witch Hill Swim Afternoon | Kickers Rock Circumnavigation
Morning | Gardner Bay Swim Afternoon | Suarez Point Coastal Swim
Morning | Floreana Bay to Bay Swim Afternoon | Cormorant Point Swim/Snorkel
Sunrise dip before heading back to land to catch your flight back to Quito

placesVisited: Quito, Isla San Cristobal, Isla Floreana, Isla Isabela, Isla Santa Cruz
generalInfo:
There are wildlife adventures and then there’s a Galapagos land based adventure holiday, and unless you’ve experienced this incredible archipelago close up, you really don’t know what you’re missing.

Experience the marine and land-based animals that have excited and enthralled biologists and nature lovers, with opportunities to explore on two feet, two wheels and on-board a boat all adding to the excitement of a Galapagos land based adventure holiday.

From learning about Darwin’s journey that inspired his theory of evolution to just marvelling at the wealth of animal activity on San Cristobal, Floreana, Isabela and Baltra, this ten day Galapagos land based adventure holiday presents a once-in-a-lifetime chance to peel back the layers of the natural world.

dayInfo.title: Quito.
dayInfo.description: Bienvenidos! Welcome to Ecuador. Sitting at an altitude of 2,850 metres, with stunning views of Volcan Pichincha, Quito is one of the most attractive cities in South America. You may even wish to arrive a day or two early and explore further beyond the city, visiting Otavalo, Cotopaxi or the Cloud Forest. Your adventure begins in Quito with a welcome meeting at 2 pm. Afterward, you'll join your local leader on a tour of the historic centre. Catch the metro to the Parque de la Alameda and visit sites such as the Basilica of the Sacred Heart of Jesus – a famous neo-Gothic church known for its facade representing Galapagos tortoises, Andean condors and Amazon alligators. You'll also visit La Compania de Jesus, considered by many to be the most beautiful church in the Americas. The tour will finish at San Francisco Square, then you'll have free time to relax or head out for dinner in Quito's Old Town – your leader will have plenty of recommendations!

dayInfo.title: Isla San Cristobal.
dayInfo.description: Catch an early morning transfer to Quito airport for your flight to San Cristobal Island in the Galapagos. The flight includes a stop in Guayaquil to pick up additional passengers (you will not need to disembark the plane). After joining up with your fellow travellers and your local naturalist guide on San Cristobal, head to La Loberia where you'll put on snorkelling gear for the first time and go for a swim among sea lions and maybe even some sea turtles! Return to town for a free evening tonight and maybe head out with the group for some fresh seafood.

dayInfo.title: Isla San Cristobal.
dayInfo.description: Take a 45-minute boat ride to Leon Dormido (Kicker Rock) this morning. On the way, you might be able to spot nesting frigates and blue-footed boobies. You might even get the chance to swim among the sea lions again. At Leon Dormido, you can snorkel and look for sea turtles, manta rays and the harmless Galapagos shark. Eat lunch on the boat, then head to the Interpretation Center. Learn about the history of the 'Enchanted Islands' and the conservation projects that seek to preserve them. Continue on your walk to Frigatebird Hill (Cerro Tijeretas) – for stunning views of the bay. Then, return to town in the late afternoon for a free evening.

dayInfo.title: Isla Floreana / Isla Isabela.
dayInfo.description: Take an early morning boat ride to Isla Floreana and look for dolphins and whales along the way. Snorkel in the clear blue waters and then break for lunch. After, venture to a black-sand beach belonging to the Witmers – descendants of some of the first settlers on the Galapagos. The town here – Puerto Velasco Ibarra – has about 150 residents and an intriguing history involving deaths, disappearances and murders. Head to a local restaurant for a traditional lunch. Continue to Isla Isabela later in the day, where you’ll settle in for the night.Later in the afternoon, wave goodbye to Floreana and continue to Isla Isabela, where you’ll spend the night.

dayInfo.title: Isla Isabela.
dayInfo.description: This morning, you’ll hop on a small Zodiac boat and cruise to Las Tintoreras (Shark Alley), looking out for blue-footed boobies and the famous Galapagos penguin. Take a short walk on this isolated islet and popular iguana nesting site, then snorkel in a calm inlet with colourful fish and winding underground lava tubes. This area is also frequented by green sea turtles that like to rest on the calm, sandy bottom. Return to Isla Isabela and visit the Arnaldo Tupiza Tortoise Breeding Center, where you'll observe giant tortoises in all stages of development. After learning about the thousand turtles that are preparing for life here, you’ll head to a brackish lagoon to observe flamingos. Later today, take a kayak around the island and spend your evening resting in the sand and soaking in your first Isabela sunset – arguably the most beautiful of all the islands!

dayInfo.title: Isla Isabela.
dayInfo.description: Start your last day on Isla Isabela by heading towards the Sierra Negra Volcano – one of the Galapagos’ most active volcanoes and the world's second-largest crater! Weather permitting, you’ll take a challenging hike of around 17 km up the rocky mountain. After, make your way back to town for some free time to curl up with a book, soak your tired muscles or venture down to the water for a relaxing swim before dinner.

dayInfo.title: Isla Isabela / Isla Santa Cruz.
dayInfo.description: Jump aboard a private speedboat this morning and head to Isla Santa Cruz. When you arrive, leave your bags at the hotel and head to the Santa Cruz Highlands. Your first stop is a local farm, where giant tortoises roam the grounds freely. Here, you’ll meet with an expert chef for a cooking class to make the famed encebollado – a local tuna soup that’s widely considered one of the best in the world! This hearty dish uses slow-cooked albacore tuna and a savoury broth made of onions, cilantro and spices. The dish is traditionally served with yuca (a starchy root vegetable) and garnished with lime and green onions. Enjoy the soups of your labour for lunch, then wander the grounds with the slow-paced residents. After lunch, you’ll visit an organic sugar cane farm run by a local family for a tour of their trapiche (a sugar cane mill used in artisanal sugar production). See how the family harvests and processes sugar cane and cacao and how they work with the local community.

dayInfo.title: Isla Santa Cruz.
dayInfo.description: Take a morning walk in Tortuga Bay after breakfast. Along the way, keep an eye out for eagle rays, sea turtles and blue-footed boobies. Later, you’ll head to the local fish market for a dose of local life on the way to The Galapagos Conservancy, who help protect the Galapagos' unique biodiversity. Learn how our Foundation supports the Galapagos Conservancy Women in Sustainable Entrepreneurship (WISE) program, which provides critical capital for sustainability initiatives and builds the entrepreneurial capacity of Galapagos women. After, head to the Charles Darwin Research Station – an international non-profit organisation that’s dedicated to the scientific research and conservation of the archipelago’s environment and biodiversity.

dayInfo.title: Quito.
dayInfo.description: Say goodbye to these enchanting islands and your Galapagos leader before taking a flight back to Quito, making a stop in Guayaquil on the way. You'll arrive in Quito later in the afternoon, where a representative will take you from the airport to your hotel. Enjoy a free evening in Quito and perhaps head out for a final dinner with your group.

dayInfo.title: Quito.
dayInfo.description: This morning, your adventure comes to an end. As there are no activities planned for today, you can depart the accommodation at any time, though we recommend staying a few extra days to see more of Ecuador. Not far from the capital, there are volcanoes, hot springs, Indigenous markets, and much more to explore. If you would like to extend your stay in Quito, just contact your booking agent to organize additional accommodation (subject to availability).

tourName: Galapagos luxury cruise, Central & Northern Islands
generalInfo: This cruise offers a fascinating exploration of the central and northern Galapagos Islands, visiting iconic sites such as North Seymour, Genovesa, and Santa Fe. The tour provides a wide variety of wildlife, including red-footed boobies, land iguanas, and marine species such as sea lions and turtles. Enjoy activities such as snorkeling, hiking, and birdwatching, all amidst stunning volcanic landscapes.

dayInfo.description: AM: Flight to Galapagos – Welcome to the Archipelago Your journey begins with a flight to the stunning Galapagos Islands. Upon arrival, our VIP representatives will assist you with all entry formalities, including the migration card ($20) and the National Park fee: $200 for adults (based on September 2024 rates) and $100 for children under 12. After a brief biosecurity check, your personal naturalist guide will greet you and escort you to our private transportation. While our team handles your luggage, you will be transferred to the Seaman Journey yacht via our comfortable tender, known locally as a "panga." This short, scenic ride takes you directly to your boutique yacht, where our team will welcome you with refreshments. Every detail is planned to ensure a smooth and comfortable arrival, allowing you to begin your Galapagos adventure in style. PM: Bartolomé Island Bartolomé Island, located off Sullivan Bay, reaches a height of 114 meters (approximately 375 feet) and offers one of the archipelago's most spectacular views. Here, you can admire volcanic cones, lunar-like craters, lava fields, and the famous tuff pinnacle, sculpted by the sea. Vegetation is sparse, but the island's two beaches are home to sea turtles, sea lions, and, at the base of the pinnacle, a small colony of Galapagos penguins. Dinner

AM: Mosquera Islet Located between North Seymour and Baltra, Mosquera Islet is one of the smallest islands in the Galapagos archipelago. Of volcanic origin and formed by geological uplift, it has no visible crater and features completely flat terrain. One of Mosquera’s most striking aspects is its vivid contrast of colors: pristine white sand beaches, crystal-clear turquoise waters, lush vegetation, and black lava rocks. It is an ideal spot for landscape photography, especially during the golden light of sunrise or sunset. PM: North Seymour – A Wildlife Sanctuary This impressive, elevated island offers an easy, flat hike through a pristine landscape. Here, nature provides an intimate spectacle of Galapagos wildlife. Observe majestic frigatebirds nesting among low bushes, while males display their bright red neck pouches, and charming blue-footed boobies perform their playful courtship dances just meters from the trail. Along the coast, playful sea lions ride the waves, while elegant swallow-tailed gulls perch gracefully on the cliffs. Our expert guides will escort you along well-maintained trails, ensuring comfortable viewing of these fascinating creatures in their natural habitat. The visit can be as active or relaxed as you prefer, with ample opportunities for observing and photographing from convenient resting points. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

AM: Genovesa Island El Barranco offers a delightful morning exploration along the southern edge of Darwin Bay. This 1.5-km trail crosses volcanic terrain and typically takes about two hours at a leisurely pace. The path leads to one of Genovesa Island’s most remarkable bird sanctuaries, where red-footed and masked boobies nest closely together. In the natural cliff cavities, you may observe storm petrels and their main predator, the short-eared owl. The dramatic coastline can be admired both from the trail and during a comfortable panga ride, where fur seals may be seen resting on the rocks. Note: This is one of only five locations in the archipelago where red-footed boobies nest, making it a particularly significant destination for wildlife enthusiasts. PM: Darwin Bay Darwin Bay was formed when the island’s crater collapsed below sea level. A wet landing brings you to a pristine white coral sand beach. The island is a prime birdwatching destination, offering sightings of red-footed and masked boobies, wandering tattlers, lava gulls, sandpipers, yellow- and black-crowned lava herons, and yellowfinches. Following the trail, you can observe red-footed boobies nesting in the mangroves. Birdwatching opportunities also include sharp-billed finches, large cactus and ground finches, Galapagos doves, and swallow-tailed gulls. Tide pools along the trail host shorebirds and marine birds such as night herons, while playful sea lions can often be seen nearby. Darwin Bay is also excellent for snorkeling, where you may encounter small reef sharks, sea turtles, and hundreds of colorful fish. Sea kayaking is available for those wishing to explore the bay from the water. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

AM: Santa Cruz South Plazas, located east of Santa Cruz Island, is part of a small group known as the Plazas Islands. Despite its modest size, it is home to some of the archipelago’s most fascinating species. The land iguanas on Plazas are smaller than their relatives on other islands. Throughout the island, you may also encounter several hybrid iguanas—offspring of a male marine iguana and a female land iguana. These unique creatures are easily recognizable by their black and gray coloring, combining the crest of a land iguana with the face and tail of a marine iguana. The island’s abundant iguana population is supported by the plentiful prickly pear cacti, their favorite food. Nesting swallow-tailed gulls can be seen among the cliffs, along with other seabirds such as Audubon’s shearwaters, red-billed boobies, frigatebirds, and brown pelicans. PM: Santa Fe Located in the southeast of the archipelago, Santa Fe was formed by tectonic uplift rather than volcanic activity, giving it mostly flat terrain. Some theories suggest it may be the oldest island in the Galapagos. Santa Fe is home to several endemic species, including the Galapagos hawk, Galapagos snake, Galapagos mockingbird, rice rats, and one of the archipelago’s two land iguana species. After disembarking in its clear, inviting waters, you will be near one of the numerous sea lion colonies. Along the trail, observe saltbush bushes and massive prickly pear cacti, whose impressive size is characteristic of oceanic islands. The island also offers excellent snorkeling opportunities, where you may swim alongside playful sea lions and colorful tropical fish. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

AM: David Rodríguez Tortoise Breeding Center Your final morning in the Galapagos includes a visit to the prestigious David Rodríguez Tortoise Breeding Center, a conservation gem dedicated to protecting San Cristóbal’s native giant tortoises. Named after a devoted park ranger who served the islands for 39 years, this advanced breeding center plays a pivotal role in preserving these magnificent creatures. Nestled in a serene setting near Cerro Colorado, the center is a scenic 40-minute drive from the port through the island’s highlands. Here, you will observe the stunning Chelonoidis chathamensis tortoises in thoughtfully designed natural habitats. Established in 2002 and refined over the years, the facility exemplifies conservation excellence within the archipelago. After this memorable encounter, our staff will ensure a smooth transfer to San Cristóbal Airport for your departure flight. Meals: Breakfast

placesVisited: Santa Cruz island, Santa Fe island, Legend or Coral cruise, Snorkelling, Santiago island, Rabida island, Isabela island, Fernandina island, Santa Cruz Highlands, Los Tuneles, Kicker Rock, Wildlife watching, Optional outdoor activities
generalInfo:
Famous as the inspiration for Charles Darwin's work on evolution, the Galapagos Islands are one of the number one destinations for a wildlife watching holiday. Boasting some of the word's best spots for snorkelling, such as Los Tuneles and Kicker Rock, many keen swimmers and divers come here to dip beneath the waves and discover an array of sea lions, manta rays, Galapagos penguins, lobsters, sea snakes and white-tipped sharks.

There are plenty of other ways to explore the coastlines, whether by kayak, walking or while relaxing aboard a cruise boat. As you go, watch out for the islands' many feathered residents, from albatross and flamingos to blue footed boobies. Just as unmissable is are the Santa Cruz Highlands, where the islands' most famous residents live: the Galapagos tortoises.

A combination of cruising and island hopping by small interconnecting planes allows us to explore almost all the hidden gems on six of these enchanted islands. During this holiday, you will stay on each of the main three islands (San Cristobal, Santa Cruz and Isabela), while having the opportunity to visit a further three of the islands. Travelling by either a small luxury cruise ship or a small aeroplane, you'll get to enjoy more time on each island than if you were getting about by the interconnecting public speedboats.

Please note that in the itinerary it notes that the Legend cruise or the Coral catamaran will be used, but that availability and price may change.

dayInfo.description: BALTRA TRANSFER IN Today you will arrive in Baltra airport (GPS) from where your English speaking guide will come and pick you up. You will first cross the Itabaca channel before you go by car to Puerto Ayora village (45 minutes). In the afternoon, you will have some free time to discover Puerto Ayora by yourself. You can also choose to go to Tortuga Bay, Charles Darwin Station or Nimfa Lagoon. Accommodation in Hotel Ikala or similar.

SANTA FE (B, L) Around 8 AM you will be picked up at your hotel to go to the harbour of Puerto Ayora. You will depart on a boat of about 12 guests on the way to Santa Fe island. It is about one hour by boat and you will have some time to snorkel around the island where you will be able to explore beautiful wildlife and majestic cliffs.Also, you will observe colonies of sea lions, blue-footed boobies, and marine iguanas. There will be served a boxlunch on board and you will get back around 3 PM to the village. Accommodation in Hotel Ikala or similar.

LEGEND / CORAL CRUISE DAY 1 (B, L, D) Today you will embark the Legend or Coral cruise. First, you will go by car to the Itabaca channel from where you will embark. You will have lunch onboard and in the afternoon you will visit Mosquera island, located between North Seymour and Baltra Islands. On Mosquera island you can snorkel to observe the beautiful underwater world and observe shorebirds such as herons and Lava Gills.
EGAS POINT (SANTIAGO) – RABIDA (B, L, D) Today you have a full day with activities at two different islands; Santiago and Rabida. At Rabida you will find the beautiful famous red beach.

URBINA BAY – TAGUS COVE (ISABELA) (B, L, D) The northern part of Isabela island and Fernandina are very special since not many people go there. You can find penguins and the flightless cormorant bird. The activities you will do are kayaking, swimming, snorkeling and walking. Accommodation in a double cabin in Legend / Coral cruise.
ESPINOSA POINT (FERNANDINA) – VICENTE ROCA POINT (ISABELA) (B, L, D) Accommodation in a double cabin in Legend / Coral cruise.

SANTA CRUZ HIGHLANDS (SANTA CRUZ) – BALTRA (GPS) (B) Today your cruise has come to an end. Before lunch you will be dropped off at Baltra airport from where you will take the flight to Isabela Island (about 45 minutes). Accommodation in Hotel Iguana Crossing or similar.

LOS TUNELES (B, S) After breakfast you will go on the most famous tour of the Galapagos islands; “Los Tuneles” which is considered the most beautiful place to do snorkeling activities in Isabela. The water is clear and calm. However, the entrance to the site is shallow and the waves can be strong, for this reason, the access can be complicated. The lava flows that passed through this area has formed unique geological formation and of course shaped like tunnels. Here you will find various marine species and beautiful flora vegetation. You will go on a exciting snorkeling activity inside an area with an extension of 800 meters and an average temperature of 20 degrees Celsius. There are large quantities of seabirds such as the Albatross, Flamingos, Blue Footed Boobies, the magnificent frigatebird. Also you can find species feeding such as tortoises, swimming iguanas, sea lions, manta rays, Galapagos penguins, lobsters, sea snakes and white-tipped sharks. Accommodation in Hotel Iguana Crossing or similar.

FREE DAY ISABELA (B) Today you have the whole day to explore Isabela by yourself. You can go biking, swimming or just relaxing at the beautiful white beach. Accommodation in Hotel Iguana Crossing or similar.

ISABELA – SAN CRISTOBAL (B) After breakfast you will take a small airplane to San Cristobal island, this takes about 45 minutes. The rest of the day you can discover Playa Mann, Las Tijeretas and the interpretation centre by yourself. Accommodation in Hotel Golden Bay or similar.

KICKER ROCK (B, L) Today you will go on a day trip to Kicker Rock where you hopefully find sharks to snorkel with them. We tested the Kicker Rock snorkeling tour. Accommodation in Hotel Golden Bay or similar.
ESPAÑOLA OR 360 OPTIONAL TOURS (B) Today you can take an optional tour to Espanola or a 360 San Cristobal tour. Accommodation in Hotel Golden Bay or similar.
TRANSFER OUT (B) Your last day on the Galapagos Islands is here! After breakfast you will be transferred out to the airport (10 minutes drive).

generalInfo:
Explore the magical Galapagos Islands on a boutique cruise. With a maximum of 20 guests onboard, these small and stylish boats get you closer to the action and away from the crowds.

After time in Quito to explore its cultural gems, embark on a full week cruise to discover giant tortoises, blue-footed boobies, and marine iguanas. Snorkel with sea turtles, hammerhead sharks, and thousands of fish. Explore volcanic islands, white sand beaches, and the deep blue sea.

Get in touch today to see which boat and itinerary suits you best!

dayInfo.description: Start your adventure in UNESCO-listed Quito, the charming capital of Ecuador. Enjoy a private walking tour of the Colonial Centre, and try out some optional cultural visits.

Fly to the Galapagos, and set sail for up to a week (flexible) around the incredible archipelago. You will explore a stunning diversity of islands, meeting the famous Giant Tortoises, Land and Marine Iguanas, Blue-Footed Boobies, and many other iconic creatures along the way. On most days you will have a chance to snorkel and swim in the ocean, where you can expect to also find Sea Turtles, Sea Lions, Hammerhead and Reef Sharks, Penguins, Rays, maybe even Whales and Dolphins.

Wave goodbye to the Galapagos, as you return to Quito for a final evening in Ecuador. We can also extend your trip to explore the flora and fauna of the Amazon Rainforest, Avenue of Volcanoes, or the misty Cloud Forest.

generalInfo:
Discover the best of the Galapagos Islands aboard a boutique first-class catamaran, offering a comfortable, sustainable and intimate way to experience this wild and remote archipelago. Spend each day snorkelling, kayaking and hiking across remote islands and bays, encountering unique wildlife and dramatic volcanic landscapes found nowhere else on earth.

Begin in Quito, Ecuador’s capital and spend two nights exploring its beautifully preserved historic centre before flying to the Galapagos archipelago, where your first-class catamaran awaits. Over the next nine days, expert naturalist guides lead you on a once-in a lifetime journey across the northern and southern islands offering a close look at the region’s unique ecosystems. In just one trip, snorkel with penguins, wander white-sand beaches, observe huge colonies of sea lions and witness the Giant Tortoise in its natural habitat.

dayInfo.description: Quito: Arrive in Quito and transfer to your boutique hotel located in the heart of the historical old town. The following day, enjoy a walking tour of the UNESCO-listed colonial centre, with optional cultural activities afterwards such as a cooking class, chocolate tour, or visits to artisanal workshops.

Bartolome: Take a morning flight to the Galapagos and embark on your small first-class catamaran, which will be home for the night eight nights. After a welcome briefing and lunch, set sail for your first excursion to Bartolome Island. Witness the archipelago's most famous panoramic view, surrounded by volcanic cones, lunar-like craters, lava fields, and the famous Toba-formed "Pinnacle Rock" and snorkel round the bay where sea turtles and a small colony of Galapagos penguins often frequent.

Mosquera & North Seymour: Embark on your first full day exploring the Galapagos Islands, navigating Mosquera Islet and North Seymour Island. Mosquera Islet is one of the smallest islands in the archipelago and is best known for its beautiful white sand beaches, turquoise waters, black lava rocks and lush green vegetation. In the afternoon, follow the trails of North Seymour Island, where you’ll have the chance to observe large colonies of frigatebirds, watch blue-footed boobies perform their iconic courtship dance, and admire the playful sea lions that frequent the coastline.

Genovesa: Often referred to as "Bird Island" due to the abundance of bird species that nest along its dramatic cliffs, Genovesa offers one of the most amazing wildlife experiences in the Galapagos. As you walk the volcanic trails of El Barranco, you may encounter Nazca boobies, storm petrels and a host of other fascinating species that call the area home. In the afternoon visit Darwin Bay, a favourite among birdwatchers, as it provides extraordinary opportunities to witness red-footed boobies, masked boobies, wandering tattlers, lava gulls, whimbrels, yellow-crowned and black-crowned lava herons, and yellow warblers.

South Plazas & Santa Fe: Begin exploring the tiny island of Plazas home to some of the Galapagos' most distinctive wildlife. Its notable residents include the Plazas land iguanas and unique hybrid iguanas, who combine the traits of both marine and land iguanas. Thought to be the oldest Island in the archipelago, Santa Fe is home to a number of endemic species like the Galapagos hawk, Galapagos snake, Galapagos mockingbird, rice rats and one of the two species of land iguanas found on the islands. Spend the afternoon, walking nearby one of the many sea lion colonies, wander the trails past salt bushes and giant prickly pear cacti and snorkel with playful sealions and tropical fish.

San Cristobal: Spend two full days exploring San Cristobal, the easternmost island and one of the oldest in the archipelago. The first day is spent visiting the Tortoise Breeding Centre, where you can witness these majestic creatures and learn about the ongoing efforts to recover the island’s giant tortoise species. In the afternoon, spend time exploring the oldest natural museum on the archipelago and gain insight into the geological and human history of the Galapagos. The following day visit Punta Pitt, a wonderful landscape home to an abundance of birds including three species of boobies: the blue-footed booby, red-footed booby and nazca booby. In the afternoon, visit the small Lobos Island, well known for its lively sea lion population. Snorkel in the island's protected channel and swim with sea lions as well as other marine species.

Espanola: Today explore the southernmost of the Galapagos islands', home to a number of endemic species, particularly the waved albatross that call the island home between April to December. In the morning, wander, snorkel or swim at the beach of Gardner Bay where sealions and even sharks can often be seen. Three species of Darwin finches can also be observed including the singing finch, the small-beaked ground finch and a sub-species of the large-billed cactus finch. In the afternoon explore Suarez Point. An excellent spot for seeing the blue-footed boobies, albatrosses, and Nazca boobies. Witness the legendary blowhole, which spurts water high into the air, reaching heights of at least 50 to 75 meters.

Floreana: An island, full of fascinating human history, dramatic landscapes and remarkable wildlife, this island is a real highlight. Begin the morning at one of the largest and most impressive flamingo lagoons, then enjoy snorkelling around Champion Islet, where sea turtles, playful sea lions and an abundance of reef fish often frequent. In the afternoon, visit the legendary Post Office, established in 1793 by whalers and still used today, as an informal mail system where travellers leave and collect postcards to hand-deliver around the world.

Santa Cruz: Spend your final morning exploring the legendary Charles Darwin Foundation before transferring to the airport for your flight back to mainland Ecuador, connecting with your international flight home.

placesVisited: Santa Cruz Island, Isabela Island, Land based Galapagos, staying in hotels, Charles Darwin Research Station, Punta Estrada, Channels of Love, Las Grietas, Puerto Villamil, Boat trip to Cape Rosa, “Wall of Tears”, Giant Tortoise Breeding Center, Hike to Sierra Negra volcanic crater, Chico Volcano, Isabela’s giant tortoises, Tintoreras Islets, Marine iguanas
generalInfo:
This Galapagos adventure holiday is a tailor made trip which is also land based, staying at hotels on the islands of Santa Cruz and Isabela. This eight day itinerary has been carefully crafted to give independent travellers plenty of time to explore these stunning islands, their cultural and natural heritage, but with the option to join small group tours along the way, guided by local experts.

Your first few days are on Santa Cruz, home to the Charles Darwin Research Centre which is a great starting point to learn about the Galapagos’ natural heritage. Then go and explore it at its myriad coves and beaches such as Punta Estrada or Las Grietas crevasses.

The second island of your stay is Isabela, the largest in the Galápagos but also the newest geologically and home to six active volcanoes. It is also home to flamingo filled mangroves, penguins, and marine iguanas, sea turtles and penguins, some of which you will hopefully see on a boat trip around the island to Cape Rosa. And where hiking to the Sierra Negra volcanic crater and Chico Volcano is a highlight for many of our guests.

Every day in the Galapagos Islands invites opportunities for wildlife watching, swimming or snorkelling as well as some cycling. Just chat with us about any adventures you would like to try out, and we can fit them into your schedule. We can also book scuba diving for experienced PADI divers.

dayInfo.description: Santa Cruz Island–Highlands–Charles Darwin Station (L). On arrival at Baltra Airport in the Galápagos, you pass through migration control to register your entry and pay the Galápagos National Park Entrance Fee (US$200 for adults, US$100 for children). Your guide will meet you outside the airport and escort you to a bus for the short ride to the Itabaca Channel. Here, we take a 5-minute crossing by barge to Santa Cruz Island, where we meet our private vehicle. Our journey across Santa Cruz Island begins with a stop in the highlands to see the magnificent Galápagos Giant Tortoises roaming freely in their natural habitat. We’ll also explore fascinating lava tunnels formed by ancient volcanic activity and admire the lush endemic vegetation of this humid region. Enjoy lunch at a local restaurant in the highlands before visiting the Charles Darwin Research Station. A 15-minute walk brings us to the Centre, where we’ll observe various species of giant tortoises and land iguanas from islands such as Santa Cruz, Española, and Pinzón. Learn about the station’s captive breeding programme, aimed at repopulating areas impacted by environmental changes. Overnight at a local hotel with breakfast included.

Santa Cruz Island – Bay Tour – Trip to Isabela Island (B,L) The morning begins with a guided tour of Santa Cruz Bay. Visit Punta Estrada, the Germans’ Beach, the Channels of Love, and Las Grietas, where you can snorkel, kayak, and spot marine birds and sea lions. Lunch is served in Puerto Ayora before we board a public speedboat for Isabela Island, one of the archipelago’s most stunning destinations. During the 2.5-hour crossing, keep an eye out for dolphins, rays, and whales. Upon arrival in Puerto Villamil, a transfer takes us to our hotel. Spend the rest of the day relaxing on Isabela’s beautiful beaches, playing volleyball, or enjoying the sunset with a refreshing drink. Overnight at a local hotel with breakfast included

Isabela Island – Wetlands & Wall of Tears Tour (B, L) In the morning, we cycle to the Wall of Tears, a sombre relic built by prisoners of Ecuador’s first penal colony. Your guide will share its fascinating and tragic history. On the way back, stop at the Orchilla Lookout for panoramic views of the coastal wetlands, Poza de los Diablos lagoon, Puerto Villamil, and the surrounding volcanoes and islets. This spot is perfect for capturing breathtaking photos. Lunch will be at a local restaurant, with the afternoon free to relax or explore independently. Overnight at a local hotel with breakfast included.

Flamingos, Breeding Centre & Concha de Perla (B, L) Start the day with a visit to a nearby semi-salty lagoon, home to endemic flamingos, white-cheeked pintails, and blue-winged teals. From here, we head to Isabela’s tortoise breeding centre to learn about the conservation efforts and repopulation programmes for these iconic creatures. Later, enjoy snorkelling at Concha de Perla, a natural lagoon where you may encounter penguins, colourful fish, stingrays, sea lions, and turtles. After lunch in a local restaurant, spend the afternoon at leisure. Overnight at a local hotel with breakfast included.

Sierra Negra Volcano Trek (B, L) Today, lace up your hiking boots for an exhilarating trek to Sierra Negra, one of the most active volcanoes in the Galápagos, with its last eruption occurring in 2005. After a brief drive, we begin the hike to the caldera rim, offering sweeping views of one of the largest volcanic craters in the world. The trek continues across the dramatic lava fields of Chico Volcano, leading to a stunning lookout point with views stretching to the northern tip of Isabela. Enjoy a packed lunch before returning to town. Overnight at a local hotel with breakfast included.

Tintoreras Islet Tour (B, L) A short boat ride takes us to Tintoreras Islet in Puerto Villamil Bay. This serene spot is home to White-Tip Reef Sharks, which can often be seen resting in the shallow canals. Following a gentle walk along the islet’s trails of lava rocks and volcanic sand, you’ll have the chance to snorkel in shallow waters teeming with marine life. Look out for penguins, sea lions, colourful fish, and marine iguanas, as well as sea birds like pelicans and blue-footed boobies. Lunch will be provided in a local restaurant, with the remainder of the day free. Overnight at a local hotel with breakfast included.

Tunnels of Cape Rosa (B, L) Today’s adventure takes us by boat to Cape Rosa on Isabela’s western side. This unique site features natural lava tunnels that stretch into the brilliant blue sea. Walking along these formations, you’ll spot sea turtles, penguins, and rays. Snorkelling here is a highlight, with rich marine life surrounding you. As we return to Isabela, keep an eye out for manta rays, especially during their mating season when they perform dramatic flips near the surface. Overnight at a local hotel with breakfast included.

Return to Santa Cruz, Transfer to Baltra, Depart (B) An early departure takes us by speedboat back to Puerto Ayora. From there, a bus transfers us across Santa Cruz Island to Baltra Airport, where you’ll check in for your return flight to the mainland (Quito or Guayaquil). For those interested, an optional inter-island flight from Isabela to Baltra is available (extra charge, advance booking required). Not available on Sundays.

tourName: Galapagos tailor made family holiday, hotel based
placesVisited: Santa Cruz Island, Charles Darwin Research Centre, Snorkelling, Boat trip to Isabela Island, Hike up Sierra Negra Volcano, Trek across Chico volcano lava fields, Boat trip to Cape Rosa, Galapagos wildlife
generalInfo:
This Galapagos family holiday is a tailor made tour, based on a carefully crafted itinerary that makes sure you and your children experience the wildlife and natural heritage of these unique islands. There is plenty of adventure and fun as well as time for chilling out at some of their most exquisite beaches and small hotels.

Starting on the main island of Santa Cruz, home to the Charles Darwin Research Centre, you can learn what the Galapagos’ natural heritage is all about. Then, relax at the beach, snorkel to see the island’s marine life just outside Puerto Ayora and keep a lookout for the island’s famous sea lions.

The second island of your stay is Isabela, the largest island in the Galápagos but also the newest geologically and home to six active volcanoes. It is also home to flamingo filled mangroves, penguins, and marine iguanas, sea turtles and penguins, some of which you will hopefully see on a boat trip around the island to Cape Rosa.

With one more night on Santa Cruz Island before flying back to Ecuador from its airport at Baltra, enjoy some more chill out time at Tortuga Bay where you can swim, surf or just soak up the wonders of this Galapagos trip of a lifetime.

Please note that we recommend this itinerary for children of seven years and above. However as it is tailor made, we can tailor the itinerary to shorten days or trips, depending on your interests and age ranges.

dayInfo.description: Arrival in Santa Cruz – Puerto Ayora and Charles Darwin Research Center (L) Fly into Baltra Airport from either Quito or Guayaquil. After meeting your guide, you’ll head through the scenic highlands of Santa Cruz to Puerto Ayora, where you’ll check into a comfortable hotel. Take a stroll along the bustling harbor, where you’re likely to spot sea lions, frigate birds, and pelicans before embarking on an afternoon guided tour of the Charles Darwin Research Center. This essential stop provides insight into the research and conservation work being done on the islands, and it’s just a 2-kilometer walk from town. If you like, bring swimwear to enjoy a refreshing dip at the nearby beach on the way back. In the evening, you’re free to choose a local restaurant for dinner. Overnight at a local hotel, breakfast included.

Snorkelling in Bahia and Speedboat to Isabela (B, L) This morning, enjoy a fantastic snorkelling trip in Bahia just outside Puerto Ayora. Here, you’ll encounter playful sea lions, colourful fish, and perhaps even a harmless reef shark. The curious sea lions often swim close by, creating memorable underwater encounters. After lunch, take a 2-hour speedboat trip to Isabela Island. Keep an eye out for dolphins or even a whale along the way! Once you arrive, you’ll feel the tranquil, laid-back vibe of Isabela, a beautiful, less-developed island with sandy beaches and a relaxed atmosphere. Settle into your hotel, then spend the afternoon and evening exploring Puerto Villamil at your own pace. Note: The speedboat ride can be bumpy, so consider bringing seasickness medication if you’re prone to seasickness. Overnight at a local hotel.

Sierra Negra Volcano Hike (B, L) Today’s adventure takes you to the Sierra Negra Volcano, one of the most active in the Galapagos, last erupting in 2005. Choose a half-day or full-day hike up the volcano. We’ll drive partway, then continue on foot to reach the crater’s edge. From here, enjoy sweeping views over one of the world’s most active calderas, and continue across the striking lava fields of Chico Volcano to a lookout with views stretching to northern Isabela. Return to town in the late afternoon for some well-earned relaxation, whether lounging in a hammock or heading down to the beach for a swim. End the day with a meal at a local restaurant of your choice. Overnight at a local hotel.

Cape Rosa Lava Tunnels and Snorkelling (B, L) A real highlight awaits today as we set off by boat from Puerto Villamil to Cape Rosa, about 45 minutes away. Walk along the unique lava tunnels that dot the coastline, where you can spot sea turtles, penguins, and rays from above. Afterward, dive into the clear waters for some of the best snorkelling, where vibrant marine life surrounds you. On the return trip, keep an eye out for manta rays. If you’re visiting during mating season, you might even see them somersaulting in the water. The afternoon is free for you to explore at your own pace. Optional: Half-day kayaking tour: Paddle out to Isabela’s bay and explore the coastal mangroves, home to an array of wildlife, from turtles to playful sea lions and diverse bird species. Return to town for a relaxed evening on the beach or exploring more of Isabela’s natural beauty. Overnight at a local hotel.

Return to Santa Cruz and Explore Tortuga Bay (B) Depart early from Puerto Villamil to catch the speedboat back to Santa Cruz, with another chance to spot ocean wildlife en route. After checking into your hotel in Puerto Ayora, spend the afternoon exploring, picking up any last-minute souvenirs, or heading back to the beach. Tortuga Bay is just a 3 km walk from town and is well worth it—an idyllic beach perfect for swimming, sunbathing, or bodysurfing in the waves. Afterward, make your way back to town for your evening in Puerto Ayora. Overnight at a local hotel.

Departure (B) We’ll take you to Baltra Airport for your flight back to mainland Ecuador. Note: This is a flexible itinerary, and you may choose to extend your stay on Isabela, Santa Cruz, or visit San Cristobal or North Seymour if you wish

generalInfo: Our goal is to ensure that you get an insider's view of life in the Galapagos islands. You'll encounter (and sometimes interact with) the archipelago's famous wildlife up close on land and in the water as well going beyond the experience of most visitors to see the daily lives of the people that call the islands home, accompanied by a Galapagueño guide every step of the way.

dayInfo.description: On arrival into Quito you will be met at the airport and taken to your hotel for the night.

Transfer to the Airport and fly from Quito to Galápagos (Santa Cruz) where you will be met in arrivals. On the way to your hotel for the night you will head of into the highlands to a special reserve of endemic vegetation occupied by the giant Galapagos tortoises, best known for their dome shaped shell and immense size. Walking the trails around the ranch, you’ll have the chance to get very close to these amazing creatures.(B)

The Island of Santa Cruz has some real gems for you to explore on your free day today. For instance you can spend time at Tortuga Bay, a beautiful white sand beach where you can swim and snorkel and might just see sharks, marine iguanas, pelicans and the occasional flamingo or take a walk and swim in the amazing rock formation of Las Grietas. However no visit to the Galapagos is complete without heading to the Charles Darwin research centre where you can learn all about the importance of the Galapagos Islands and also have another chance to get up close and personal with some Giant Tortoise that for one reason or other cannot live in the wild any more. (B)

Bartolomé Island (Spanish: Isla Bartolomé) is a volcanic islet just off the east coast of Santiago Island. It is one of the "younger" islands in the Galápagos archipelago. This island, and Sulivan Bay on Santiago island, are named after naturalist and lifelong friend of Charles Darwin, Sir Bartholomew James Sulivan, who was a Lieutenant aboard HMS Beagle. . It has two visitor sites. At the first one, you may swim and snorkel around Pinnacle Rock; the underwater world there is really impressive. You can snorkel with the Galapagos penguins, marine turtles, white tipped reef sharks, and other tropical fish. The bay is also an excellent place to go swimming. (B/L)

Walk to Puerto Ayora Dock where you will take a water taxi out to the public speed boat that will take you to the stunning Island of Isabela. On arrival you will be met and transferred to your hotel. In the afternoon you can stretch the legs and explore the Isabela wetlands home to a plethora of birdlife, including flamingos. (B)

This morning you will be taken to a forgotten marine paradise and one of the best places to snorkel in the Galapagos. Around a 30 - 40 minute boat ride from Puerto Villamil, Los Tuneles are formed by convoluted lava formations standing between mangroves and the open sea. Due to its remote but exquisite location, Los Tuneles is unique as it is not a part of any cruise itinerary. You can expect t snorkel with White Tipped Reef Sharks, Green Turtles, Manta Rays. Sea Lions and Sea Horses. (B/L)
