An 18km long route on the flank of the volcano Sierra Negra heads uphill to the edge of the crater. The volcano is 1500m high and with a crater diameter of around 9km, this is the second-largest volcano on earth. On the edge of the crater you will walk to volcano Chico, which last erupted in 1979. From there you have a good view of the distant volcanoes Alcedo and Wolf. Sierra Negra has some of the most beautiful and breath taking scenery in the whole Archipelego. (B)

Las Tintoreras are a small group of islands off the coast of Isabela that form a series of sea channels where white tipped reef sharks doze and playful sea lion pups give chase. It’s a magical place for observing the amazing marine wildlife of Isabela’s emerald green waters; marine iguanas and the Galápagos penguin can also be seen here. One of our local guides will lead you on foot from the dock, over a small bay onto the beach to Las Tintoreras. At the nearby sea lion colony you can snorkel in the water where newborn sea lions learn to swim amongst shoals of colourful fish. Later in the afternoon you will take the boat back over to Santa Cruz for your last night in the Galapagos Islands. (B)
Transfer to Baltra airport for your flight to Quito. (B)

generalInfo:
Sail deep into the untouched western Galapagos on a 7-day expedition cruise aboard the Galapagos Seaman Journey, that explores the volcanic heart of the archipelago. Focused on the wild, younger islands of Isabela and Fernandina, this immersive journey offers close encounters with rare wildlife and surreal landscapes formed by fire, ocean, and time.

Aboard the Galapagos Seaman Journey, you'll enjoy close encounters with rare wildlife and surreal landscapes shaped by fire, ocean, and time. Walk across lava fields where marine iguanas bask in black-armored colonies, kayak alongside penguins and flightless cormorants, and snorkel in pristine coves teeming with sea turtles, reef sharks, and rays. Onboard a comfortable motor catamaran, each day brings a new remote landing—whether it’s the flamingo-filled shores of Rábida, the red-sand contrasts of Chinese Hat, or the wildlife-rich cliffs of Vicente Roca Point.

On land, discover ancient pirate graffiti, lagoons fringed with mangroves, and coastal trails where land iguanas and Galapagos doves roam. At sea, drift through quiet channels in search of mating turtles and breaching rays. With expert naturalist guides leading the way, you'll experience the Galapagos in its rawest form—remote, alive, and constantly evolving.

This is more than a cruise—aboard the Galapagos Seaman Journey, it’s a true expedition into one of the most biologically unique and geologically active corners of the planet.

dayInfo.description: (Flight to Galapagos) Today, you will fly to the Galapagos Islands. Upon arrival at the airport, you will pay a fee of $20 USD for the migration control card before proceeding through security. After landing in Santa Cruz, you will go through an inspection point designed to prevent the introduction of foreign plants and animals. Here, you will also pay the entrance fee to the Galapagos National Park, which is $200 USD for foreign passengers and $100 USD for children under 12 years old, as of September 2024. Your guide will meet you at the airport, assist with your luggage, and escort you to the bus for the ferry crossing to the Itabaca Channel. You will then visit Ranch Manzanillo or a similar farm located in the highlands of Santa Cruz Island. It is recommended to wear comfortable shoes and light clothing, and to bring a waterproof jacket, sunblock, a camera, and repellent. You will enjoy a picnic lunch and a short walk before boarding the Motor Catamaran. Your luggage will be transferred directly to the M/C Seaman Journey yacht. In Santa Cruz, you will have the opportunity to observe wild Galapagos tortoises. You will also explore lava tubes, sinkholes, and craters found in the highlands. Following this visit, you will travel aboard the M/C Seaman Journey. Meals: Dinner

(Isabela Island - Moreno Point & Fernandina Island - Mangle Point) AM: Moreno Point, Isabela Island. Punta Moreno is situated on the west coast of Isabela Island, at the entrance of the Bolivar Channel. The trail at this site follows a Pahoehoe lava flow, leading into coastal lagoons. Here, you can spot various bird species, including blue-footed boobies and flightless cormorants, often seen near the lakes and mangroves. PM: Mangle Point, Fernandina Island. Mangle Point, located off Fernandina’s eastern coast, is an excellent site for snorkeling. You will take a panga or zodiac ride through mangrove groves. During this excursion, you may encounter sea lions, tortoises, pelicans, rays, and numerous sea birds. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Isabela Island - Urbina Bay & Tagus Cove) AM: Urbina Bay, Isabela Island. Urbina Bay is located at the base of Alcedo Volcano on Isabela’s west coast. This area experienced a significant geological uplift in 1954, which stranded marine life. The site offers excellent snorkeling opportunities and features a 3,200-meter trail composed of sand, pumice, lava, coral, and coastal vegetation. During your visit, look for iguana burrows, and while snorkeling, you may swim alongside penguins and observe red and blue lobsters. Here, you might also see Darwin’s finches and land iguanas, which are notably larger than those found on South Plaza Island. Giant Tortoises also roam the area. The vegetation includes chamomile, Rosewood, and Darwin’s cotton flowers, all endemic to the Galapagos. PM: Tagus Cove, Isabela Island. Tagus Cove, located west of Darwin Volcano, was a favored spot for pirates and whalers; it is possible to observe pirate graffiti from the 1800s in a cave. The area is known for its volcanic rocks, including “lapilli” (small spherical rocks). The trail, which presents a small challenge, leads to a lookout point above Darwin Lake and the bay below. Along the trail, you can spot finches and mockingbirds. This is also a very good site for snorkeling and sea kayaking, and a colony of flightless cormorants resides here. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Fernandina Island - Espinoza Point & Isabela Island - Vicente Roca Point) AM: Espinoza Point, Fernandina Island. Espinoza Point is renowned for its extensive marine iguana colonies, which appear like armies covering vast areas. It is also home to unique species such as the flightless cormorant, Galapagos penguin, Galapagos hawk, and Galapagos snake. This location is considered one of the most pristine and remote areas within the Galápagos archipelago. PM: Vicente Roca Point. Vicente Roca Point, situated on Isabela’s northwestern coast, is characterized by its high cliffs and distinctive lava formations. This bay is exceptionally rich in marine life, where you can look for seahorses, sea turtles, and Mola-mola (sunfish). Guests can enjoy panga rides and snorkeling to observe penguins, blue-footed boobies, terns, and sea lions. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Santiago Island - Espumilla Beach & Puerto Egas) AM: Espumilla Beach and Bucaneer Cove, Santiago Island. Espumilla Beach is located on Santiago Island’s northern coast, within James Bay. This site features a very picturesque coastline, displaying erosion and unique formations sculpted by the action of the sea. Explore the palo santo forest and mangroves, and observe nesting baby sea turtles in the sand dunes, as well as a Flamingo colony in the coastal lagoon. The vegetation here varies within short distances, from dry to humid, showcasing the damage caused by introduced species like feral goats, which have since been eradicated. Key wildlife includes sea lions and fur seals, marine turtles, marine iguanas, oystercatchers, herons (great blue heron), and various other sea birds. You can also spot land birds such as the Galapagos dove, Darwin’s finches, and hawks. Snorkeling is possible from the soft beach, whose name "Espumilla" (foam) comes from a typical Ecuadorian Andes dessert. Marine life here includes playful sea lions, white-tipped reef sharks, sea turtles, manta rays, and numerous reef fish. PM: Puerto Egas, Santiago Island. Puerto Egas features a black beach composed of volcanic tuff deposits, creating a vibrant contrast between the dark minerals and the red sally-lightfoot crabs scattered across the rocks. This site was historically used for salt extraction but operations ceased due to low prices on the continent, with remnants of the abandoned infrastructure still visible. The trail passes a sea lion colony and leads to a playful grotto where fur seals (smaller than sea lions) swim and play in the tidal pools. Snorkeling here allows encounters with marine iguanas, playful sea lions, and other diverse marine life. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Rabida Island & Chinese Hat) Rábida Island is distinctive for its red rocks and sand. The volcanic material here is porous and changes color due to oxidation. A short trail leads to a lagoon where you can observe land birds and a colony of flamingos. It is interesting to watch pelicans diving for fish. The red beach contrasts beautifully with the surrounding green vegetation. Snorkeling here is considered among the best, as you swim along the coastline and playful sea lions often join you. You may spot moray eels, small sharks, starfish, and many colorful fish. PM: Chinese Hat Chinese Hat is a small islet situated off Santiago Island’s southeastern tip. This recent volcanic cone strikingly resembles a Chinese hat. Exploration includes walking through lava formations and observing sea lion colonies, lava lizards, marine iguanas, and Galapagos penguins. This island is characterized by colorful contrasts, with red vessuvium flowers, sally lightfoot crabs, and the orange beaks of American oystercatchers providing a beautiful visual contrast against the pahoehoe lava fields and lava cacti. It is also an excellent spot for deep water snorkeling; the channel formed between Sombrero Chino and Santiago Island creates a protected area with calm turquoise waters, yet deep enough to attract white-tipped reef sharks that rest in small caves below. You can also observe stingrays, parrotfish, Galapagos penguins, marine turtles, and with luck, dolphins and the rare visit of whale sharks. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Santa Cruz Island - Black Turtle Cove) AM: Black Turtle Cove, Santa Cruz Island Enjoy a calm dinghy ride to Black Turtle Cove on Santa Cruz’s north coast. The boat will explore the mangrove-protected cove with its engines off. In these calm waters, you may observe sea turtles feeding and mating, alongside black-tip, white-tip, and Galapagos sharks. You can also spot groups of spotted rays, golden cow rays, egrets, and herons. After this visit, you will be transferred to Baltra airport for your flight back to the mainland. Meals: Breakfast

placesVisited: Wildlife watching, Professional guide, Full board, Ensuite bathrooms
generalInfo:
Going on a cruise is a great way to explore the 19 islands of the Galápagos and the surrounding marine reserve. Our Galapagos cruises offer you a decent room and a great view on all the islands. The cruises will bring you to all the highlights of the most popular islands and they will send a professional guide with you. The advantage of going on a cruise is that you are able to visit remote and unreachable places like the western northern uninhabited islands, the western part of Isabela or islands like Rabida and Egas Port. Those are the most biodiverse regions of the Galapagos, where you can possibly see Killer whales, Galapagos Penguins, Hammerhead sharks and four different sea lion species in one place. When you go home, you will know everything about the evolution, the volcanoes and about all the animals. You will visit all the beautiful cliffs, beaches and volcanoes. You will meat the giant tortoises and other animals and sea creatures on these islands, which inspired Charles Darwin to his evolution theory.

By going on a cruise, you will visit two spots a day, you will get 3 meals a day and, depending on the service, also drinks.
There are about 50 independent cruise boats on the Galápagos, so there is a boat available for each budget and there are different service levels. We can offer you different types of cruises.

There are four types of classes; Tourist, Tourist Superior, Luxe and First class. If you are interested in one specific boat please contact us!

The main differences between the boat classes are the guides (on Luxe and First class boats usually guides with a degree in biology or geography), the common spaces on board (on Luxe and First class boats sometimes have living room, sun deck, tv room or jacuzzi), on Tourist and Tourist Superior class boats there are mainly cabins with bunkbeds available and on Luxe and First class boats the cabins are bigger and there is space for a queen or sometimes even king size bed. At some First class boats the cabins even have a private balcony available. All boats we offer do have their private bathroom per room (2 people) but the quality and duration of hot water and the size and facilities of the bathroom depend strongly on the class.

dayInfo.description: First Day - Welcome in the Boat - First activity
Second Day - Two activities depending on the selected cruise.
Third Day - Two activities depending on the selected cruise.
Fourth Day - Two activities depending on the selected cruise.
Fifth Day - Two activities depending on the selected cruise.
Sixth Day - Two activities depending on the selected cruise.
Seventh Day - Two activities depending on the selected cruise.
Eight Day - Last Activity - Goodbye Drink

generalInfo:
This 8-day island-hopping journey across the Galapagos offers a front-row seat to one of the planet’s most extraordinary natural spectacles. From the volcanic highlands of Isabela to the iconic viewpoints of Bartolome and the wildlife-rich waters around North Seymour, this adventure brings you face to face with the raw beauty and biodiversity of the archipelago.

The trip begins on Isabela Island, where you’ll hike to the rim of Sierra Negra Volcano and snorkel among sea lions and reef sharks at Tintoreras Islet. Explore lava tunnels, crystal-clear coves, and spot blue-footed boobies and marine iguanas as you discover otherworldly landscapes shaped by fire and time. On Santa Cruz, you'll wander lava tubes and walk beside giant tortoises in the lush highlands before relaxing at Tortuga Bay’s striking beaches.

Sailing tours to nearby uninhabited islands—like Bartolome, North Seymour, Santa Fe, or Plazas—bring close encounters with unique Galapagos species and dramatic scenery. Every day offers chances to snorkel, hike, and explore, whether you're swimming alongside sea turtles or photographing surreal volcanic formations.

The tour ends with a visit to the Charles Darwin Research Station, where conservation comes to life. With expert guides, seamless transfers, and carefully curated excursions, this trip is perfect for travelers seeking a dynamic and immersive Galapagos experience.

dayInfo.description: (Quito / Guayaquil – Baltra – Puerto Ayora – Isabela) Begin with a flight from Quito or Guayaquil to Baltra’s airport. Upon arrival, a naturalist guide will transfer you to Puerto Ayora. After lunch in town, you will proceed to the port to embark on a public speedboat to Isabela Island (approximately 2 to 2.5 hours of navigation). A local contact will then take you to your hotel for check-in. The day concludes with a visit to the Flamingo Lagoon, followed by dinner and accommodation at your hotel. Note: For this itinerary, it is essential to select an early flight arriving at Baltra by maximum 10:00 AM. Meals: Lunch / Dinner

(Full Day Isabela) Around 7:30 AM, your private trip to Sierra Negra Volcano start. You will be transported for approximately 45 minutes to the Galapagos National Park control site. From there, you will begin a trek to the Sierra Negra and Chico Volcanoes, with a box lunch provided during the trek. In the afternoon, you will return to your hotel before preparing for a visit to Tintoreras Islet. You will embark on small speedboats from the Puerto Villamil dock. After a brief ride (approximately 20 minutes), you will arrive at Tintoreras. Following a hike across the islet, you will have the opportunity to snorkel. Underwater, you may encounter starfish, multicolored fish, sea urchins, and with luck, manta rays, sharks, and sea lions swimming very close to you. You will then return to Isabela for dinner and accommodation. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Half Day Isabela) Located 40 minutes from Puerto Villamil, your first visit site is Roca Union, where you can observe masked pikemen. You will then proceed to Los Tuneles (The Tunnels), a unique geological formation created by lava flow from the Sierra Negra volcano, resulting in natural arches, points, tubes, and tunnels both above and below water. At this site, you can enjoy a short 10-15 minute walk to observe the volcanic formations and various birds. Next, you will visit El Finado, a secluded cove with crystal-clear, calm waters, perfect for snorkeling among mangroves and swimming near sea turtles, reef fish, and resting sharks. A box lunch is included. You will then return to Isabela for a free afternoon, followed by dinner and accommodation. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Isabela – Santa Cruz) At 5:30 AM, you will be transferred to the port for a public speedboat to Santa Cruz (approximately 2 to 2.5 hours of navigation). Upon arrival, you will be transferred to your hotel for check-in and breakfast. Your guide will then pick you up for a trip to the highlands of Santa Cruz, where you will observe giant tortoises in their natural habitat. The Highlands of Santa Cruz are notably lush green, contrasting beautifully with the drier lower islands, with scalessia trees being the dominant vegetation. You will also explore lava tubes, extending over half a mile underground, offering a unique and surreal walking experience. After lunch in town, you will visit Tortuga Bay. This involves an approximate 45-minute walk along a cactus trail to Playa Brava, known for its strong currents and abundant marine iguanas, marine birds, and pelicans. Following Playa Brava, a 15-minute walk leads to Playa Mansa, a natural lagoon frequented by blue-footed boobies and pelicans, ideal for swimming and relaxation. You will then walk the same distance back to your hotel for dinner and accommodation. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Sailing Tours) On one of these days, you will visit either Bartolome or North Seymour or Plazas or Santa Fe Island. After breakfast, your guide will meet you in the hotel lobby to take you to the dock and commence the tour. Lunch will be provided onboard the small yacht. In the afternoon, you will return to the port. North Seymour Island is an excellent location for hiking, swimming, and snorkeling, with key attractions including frigates, boobies, gulls, hawks, green sea turtles, and Galapagos Sharks. Bartolome Island is celebrated for its iconic landscape, being the most photographed island in the Galapagos, offering spectacular views of two beautiful bays and fascinating lava formations and volcanic cones. Plazas Islands comprise two islands, where the turquoise waters of the channel beautifully contrast with the white sand and black lava coast. It is a prime spot for observing marine life, including manta rays, with coasts ideal for snorkeling. Santa Fe Island (also called Barrington Island), a small island of 24 square kilometers (9.3 sq mi) located in the center of the Galapagos archipelago, southeast of Santa Cruz Island. Geologically, it is one of the oldest, with volcanic rocks dating back approximately 4 million years. Its vegetation is characterized by brush, palo santo trees, and a large variety of the prickly pear cactus Opuntia echios. The chosen island for the sailing tour will depend on available spaces. You will then return to your hotel for dinner and accommodation. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Santa Cruz – Baltra) In the early morning, you will visit the Charles Darwin Station. Here, you will observe various species of Giant Tortoises and learn about ongoing conservation efforts aimed at preserving both the Giant Tortoises and the archipelago's environment. Afterwards, you and your guide will take the approximately 1-hour route to the airport. At the airport, you will board your flight back to Quito or Guayaquil. Meals: Breakfast

placesVisited: Otavalo market, Historic haciendas, Imbabura volcano, San Pablo Lake, Zuleta Valley, Pesillo plains, Cayambe Valley, Cotopaxi National Park, Quito
generalInfo:
An eight-day small group horse riding holiday across the altiplano, offering a unique way to experience the wide-open spaces and breathtaking views of Ecuador’s High Andes.

You set off from a farm nestled in the foothills near Quito, riding ancient Incan paths towards the snow-capped Antisana volcano. Cross some of Ecuador’s most spectacular landscapes, past the impressive Cayambe and Cotopaxi volcanoes to reach beautifully conserved, historic haciendas at the end of each day.

Your expert guide will also give you a chance to get to know more about local flora and fauna and introduce you to Ecuador’s colourful indigenous cultures along the way.

This specific trip is aimed at intermediate riders. However, tours can be designed for all levels of horse-riding ability from beginner to advanced. Families, small groups, individuals or couples can also be catered for if required.

The riding pace is governed by the landscape and riders’ experience. On tours catering for intermediate or more advanced riders, you will be able to canter across open fields and negotiate tricky terrain. For beginners, lessons can be arranged prior to departure.

The local partner for this small group holiday is English and has been running highly recommended horse riding tours in Ecuador since 1996. Locally-bred horses are ideally suited to the terrain.

Being set in the High Andes, riding takes place at altitudes up to over 4000m, so it is recommended that you arrive in Quito a few days prior to the start of the tour to ensure you can acclimatise.

Horses, guides, grooms, meals as listed in the itinerary, accommodation, park fees, transfers and transport of luggage are all included.

dayInfo.description: Introductory ride, hacienda (L,D) Heading northwards from Quito, after a quick stop on the equator line, we meet the horses and, once everyone is comfortable, head out along the grassy lanes. Having admired the magnificent view atop a hill carpeted with wild flowers, we descend to a family run Hacienda in a beautiful pastoral valley. This small working farm with a dairy herd and Andalusian (PRE) horses is the perfect location to leisurely drift into the relaxing Andean atmosphere. Once settled in at the six-room hacienda, guests can view the collection of Inca and pre-Inca ceramics discovered on site. Riding time: 2hr drive, 4-5 hours riding B = Breakfast L = Lunch D = Dinner

Imbabura, San Pablo Lake, hacienda (B,L,D) Today, we ride past tiny hamlets of adobe huts, the ladies in their brightly coloured full skirts herding sheep and pigs. We ride through woodlands, and wind our way around the patchwork fields of quinoa, potatoes, maize, lupins and tree tomato orchards. There are magnificent views of the jagged Mojanda summit as we cross the slopes of the sacred Imbabura volcano — the focus of many pre-Inca legends. Nearing our stay for the night, a 17th-century hacienda, we pass avocadoes, papaya, passionfruit and, riding into the Hacienda courtyard, graced with bougainvillea, the hummingbirds zoom past us enroute to the agapanthus. A blast of dazzling Andean colour is provided on a visit to the famous Otavalo market. Riding time: 5-6 hours riding

Weavers, Zuleta Valley, hacienda (B,L,D) After a fascinating demonstration by local master weavers and a chance to purchase top quality Andean handicrafts, we ride out of the Hacienda. Climbing out the valley onto the plains, we pick up the pace and, following agave-lined sandy tracks, ride through a landscape frequently described by guests as the most picturesque they have ever seen. Dramatic views of the hanging valleys and rocky ridges as we descend to lush meadows below passing ladies in traditional dress embroidering intricate blouses as they watch their flocks. We stop to see the pre-Inca earthworks dotted around this valley -one of the first highland areas settled, also often pausing in awe at the sight of a mighty Andean condor soaring overhead. Afternoon drive to a very comfortable country hotel located at the trail head of the next part of our ride. Jacuzzi & sauna at this very comfortable lodge. Riding time: 6 hours horse riding, 2.5hrs drive

Ride towards Cotopaxi, hacienda (B,L,D) First riding along lanes between the meadows, riders get used to their new horses. Alongside the gurgling river, the abundance of lush vegetation is quite surprising: montane bamboo, ferns and native trees dripping with orchids and bromelias. The birds such as woodpeckers and hummingbirds are wonderful to see, the vultures a little unnerving! As we leave the micro-climate of the river valley, extensive views open up before us. Surrounded by four Andean peaks, part of the Avenue of Volcanoes, we ride towards the iconic Cotopaxi Volcano. Riding onto rough grasslands in the Sincholagua foothills there is a good chance of seeing more Andean Condors as well as eagles, hawks, falcons and harriers. At the northern border of the Cotopaxi National Park we arrive at a modern hacienda, often greeted by the llamas. This idyllic location, with remarkable views of the marvellous Andean landscape encircling us, is dominated by the perfectly conical shape of the snow-capped Cotopaxi Volcano. It will be our base for two nights. Riding time: 6 hours

Cotopaxi National Park, hacienda (B,L,D) We ride into Cotopaxi National Park on our adorable sure-footed criollo horses for some exhilarating canters across the wide, arid plains at the base of the Cotopaxi volcano. The horses enjoy the open spaces but have such a calm temperament that they settle into a rhythm without trying to rush. Several herds of wild horses inhabit the park and to ride alongside these long-maned horses galloping freely across the rugged terrain is a unique experience. Part of this ride follows the main Inca highway which linked Quito with Cusco, Peru, then we turn eastwards to follow the Inca route leading down to the Amazon. We pause to visit the remains of an Inca fort before continuing on through the gently undulating grassy hills, passing drumlins and moraine, crossing lahas and old lava flows before returning to the Hacienda via a canyon. We return to the same hacienda. Riding time: 6 hours

High passes, cliffs, and wild horses, hacienda (B,L,D) We head up the slopes of Rumiñahui Volcano (stoneface) with an excellent chance of close encounters with the Andean condor, fox and deer. We pass polylepis trees (‘paperbark trees’), native shrubs such as chuquiragua and valeriana and a host of colourful wild flowers hugging the hillsides. Rising above 4,000m/13,132ft and experiencing one of the highest canters in the world, we then ride on into a hidden valley often seeing wild horses grazing close to the towering cliffs. The views are unforgettable and the picnic spot unmatchable. The trails, marked out by the wild horses, take us back down and on to a once important and now historic Jesuit Hacienda recently restored and now a delightful place to stay. Riding time: 6-7 hours

Avenue of the Volcanoes, hacienda (B,L,D) The final ride takes us on an exhilarating canter across the flat expanses of Cotopaxi National Park close to the volcano where we traverse old lava, volcanic ash and lahas. We then veer westwards and start a long ascent with outstanding views. Riding up through the native grasslands in order to reach the scree slopes and cross over into the Avenue of the Volcanoes, we leave the national park. We often meet local horsemen (chagras) checking their cattle, quite a sight, with their colourful ponchos, thick goatskin chaps and intricately plaited bridles. Their stirrups are enclosed, like clogs, and often carved into an animal head. Their lassos seem impossibly long to be useful – but very necessary when working with their very feisty bulls: they lasso the animal then get as far away as possible. We leave the horses and are driven to a historic hacienda with large gardens, close to Quito airport for dinner and overnight. Riding time: 6-7 hours, 2hr drive
Following breakfast, guests are accompanied to the airport in time for their outward flights, or are picked up at their hotel to continue on extensions. Meals: Breakfast.

tourName: Island hopping holiday in the Galapagos
generalInfo: Between shark and sea lion-patrolled waters, highlands of plodding giant tortoises, and a landscape forged in the belly of volcanoes, the Galapagos has become the destination for nature lovers. Join this trip to discover four of the great islands: Santa Cruz, San Cristóbal, Floreana and Isabela. Along the way, there are plenty of chances to meet the extraordinary sea life on various snorkelling adventures, while also taking time to tread lava-forged plains and spectacular highlands – an unforgettable adventure in the Enchanted Islands.

dayInfo.description: Begin the adventure in Quito, Ecuador’s capital, high in the Andes. To make things easy, there are free transfers from the airport to the hotel for everyone today – check the Joining Instructions for further details. Around 6pm, say hola to your Quito tour leader and fellow travellers, when we gather as a group for the first time to get to know each other and learn more about the adventures ahead. Want more time in Quito? Secure pre-tour hotel nights through your sales representative. Classic accommodation: Hotel Wyndham (or similar) Upgrade to a junior suite today – speak to your sales representative for more details

Leave the hotel around 5am – taking a box breakfast with you – for our transfer (50 minutes) to Quito Airport, where we catch our flight to San Cristóbal in the Galapagos via Guayaquil. Our Galapagos tour leader (an official naturalist guide) will be at the airport to take you to the hotel for check-in and our first briefing about our time in the archipelago. We have time to explore the town and enjoy a restaurant lunch before our visit to La Lobería, a wonderful place surrounded by mangroves, volcanic rocks and sea lion colonies. It’s a perfect spot to snorkel, enjoy time on the beach, or have a short walk along the shore. Your tour leader ensures a big Ecuadorian welcome by arranging a group dinner tonight. Accommodation: Hotel Paraiso Insular (or similar)

Start your day with an exciting tour to Isla Lobos, a small island near San Cristóbal. This excursion takes you by boat to one of the best spots for observing sea lions in their natural habitat. Isla Lobos is also an excellent location for birdwatching, including frigatebirds and blue-footed boobies. Snorkel in the clear waters around the island, swimming with marine turtles, rays and, occasionally, whitetip reef sharks. After, we head to Playa Ochoa, a white-sand beach with turquoise waters. It’s ideal for relaxing, while also offering excellent birdwatching and snorkelling opportunities. Enjoy lunch on board the boat as we head back to town for a free afternoon. Accommodation: Hotel Paraiso Insular (or similar)

A three-hour navigation by motorboat takes us to Floreana Island, one of the first Galapagos islands to be inhabited. En route, we may see whales, dolphins and sea birds. After lunch at a local restaurant, we visit the highlands, where one of the few sources of freshwater in the entire archipelago exists. We also visit lava caves once used by pirates and see a large enclosure of Galapagos giant tortoises. In the afternoon, we’ll transfer to Isabela Island by speedboat (approximately 2.5 or 3 hours). Accommodation: San Vicente Hotel (or similar)

Spend 15 minutes sailing to the islets and lava channels of Las Tintoreras, one of the best places in the Galapagos to see whitetip reef sharks, penguins and sea lions. A 40-minute walk takes us to an excellent place to snorkel! This afternoon, we visit the Wall of Tears, a sad reminder of Isabela’s very different past when it was used as a penal colony. Between 1946 and 1959, convicts were forced to build this wall from huge blocks of lava as a form of punishment, which, combined with the harsh conditions, led to many deaths. Accommodation: San Vicente Hotel (or similar)

Navigate by motorboat to Santa Cruz very early this morning. Upon arrival, we have the option of visiting the Charles Darwin Research Centre, home to the headquarters of the Charles Darwin Foundation. This is the main research centre on the islands and scientists come from all over the world to study the flora and fauna. In the afternoon, we visit Tortuga Bay, a 3,280ft (1,000m) stretch of white sand regarded as one of the best beaches in the Galapagos. The trail leading to the beach is paved and takes between 45 minutes to one hour, with possibilities to observe Galapagos finches and lizards along the way. The beach is scattered with marine iguanas, who lay among the clusters of black rocks or stroll along the sand. In the water, turtles can sometimes be seen, though swimming is not recommended here due to the strong currents. Accommodation: Grand Hotel León Marino (or similar)

Visit either Bartolomé Island, South Plaza Island, Santa Fe Island or North Seymour (depending on the national park restrictions). South Plaza Island has a remarkable vegetation of succulents and cacti that provide a unique habitat for land iguanas. The iguanas form small colonies at the base of the tall opuntia cacti, waiting for their flowers and dead pads to fall to the ground so they can feed on them. The island rocks are home to swallowtail gulls, shearwaters and sea lions. North Seymour is a flat, boulder-strewn island and a major nesting site for frigatebirds. It’s also a good place to see blue-footed boobies performing courtship rituals and sea lions playing in the powerful surf. Bartolomé is a spectacular scene of dramatic lava cones, clear seas and affords perhaps the most famous view of the Galapagos Islands, looking across the red cinder cones to the recent black lava fields on James Island. If possible, we snorkel today where the water is calm. Lunch is on board the boat. Accommodation: Grand Hotel León Marino (or similar)

After a few days following the footsteps of Darwin, Cousteau and world-renowned scientists, it is time to say goodbye to the Enchanted Islands. After breakfast, we drive to Baltra Airport – bidding a fond farewell to our Galapagos tour leader – and fly to Quito via Guayaquil. Our Quito tour leader meets us upon arrival and our groups normally gather for a final dinner this evening, a chance to celebrate the adventures we’ve had together. Accommodation: Hotel Vieja Cuba (or similar) Upgrade to a suite today – speak to your sales representative for more details
Our adventure ends after breakfast this morning and we begin our return journeys home. If you’d prefer a little time to explore, speak to your sales representative about extending your stay in Quito.

tourName: Luxury Ecuador and Galapagos tailor made holiday
generalInfo:
Situated on the equator, Ecuador is the smallest country in the Andean Highlands. Despite its size, it is probably the world's most bio-diverse country, crammed with an astounding variety of wildlife, birds and vegetation existing in contrasting climatic zones.

With its beautiful colonial architecture, magnificent panoramic scenery, vibrant indigenous groups and welcoming people. Ecuador is one of the most enticing and rewarding countries to visit in South America. And, as if it needed any further promotion, one of the world's greatest treasures of natural history lies in the bewitching Galapagos Islands, famed for the fearless and unique wildlife that inspired Charles Darwin, the island chain is roundly considered the highlight of any holiday in Ecuador.

Many travellers consider a visit to the Galapagos the most epic and coveted wildlife destination on the planet - and for good reason. The choice of itineraries and options an be overwhelming, but if you're going to do this just once, we highly recommend doing it in style! With first hand experience of the most delightful accommodations, expert local guides and a thorough understanding of the logistics, we can help you craft the best itinerary for the most memorable trip.

dayInfo.description: Arrival transfer into the heart of Quito, staying at the stunning Relais & Chateaux Casa Gangotena. Quito, the capital of Ecuador, lies on the slopes of the Andes’ mighty Pichincha volcano in the Guayllabamba river basin. The city’s Old Town is its main attraction - one of the most well preserved in Latin America and the first-ever UNESCO heritage site. Wander among ancient, colourful streets; pop into glorious historic churches; or spend an afternoon browsing the vibrant Mercado (markets) and learning about the unique, traditional Ecuadorian Sierra culture. Numerous gorgeous public parks and a thriving and exciting culinary scene complete the package.

A TASTE OF OLD TOWN QUITO Experience a culinary journey through Quito, tasting its most popular flavors and traditions with our Taste of Old Town Quito tour. This full-day tour takes you to the most iconic food spots and cultural experiences, perfectly showcasing the heritage of the city, with a focus on Ecuadorian cuisine.

Wild Cotapaxi. Embark on an incomparable full day adventure through the breathtaking landscapes of Cotopaxi. Encounter one of the highest active volcanoes in the world, explore an hacienda with a history that dates back six centuries, and enjoy a unique vodka tasting afternoon.

Mashpi Biodiversity Reserve Located in the northwest corner of the Metropolitan District of Quito, the Mashpi Biodiversity Reserve stands out as a unique and extraordinary destination. Encompassing an expansive area of 2800 hectares, this reserve encompasses both cloud forest and rainforest, contributing to the globally-significant Choco biodiversity hotspot. Recognised as one of the most important eco-lodges in Ecuador, this immersive and active experiencce really is something special.

Mashpi Lodge does not have a set programme and the expert guides will organise the day around your preferences. You could start at sunrise on the panoramic terrace, watching -and hearing- a flock of birds flying around the lodge. After breakfast, you can walk to a waterfall, bathe in the dramatic water jet, and then head to the Hummingbird Garden. Another option is to discover the wonderful butterflies at the Life Center. After lunch, you can cycle between two points in the forest about 200m apart on the Aerial Bike, followed by reaching and climbing the Observation Tower to enjoy the Reserve in its entirety and watch the sun set behind the mountains and clouds…
Puembo Depart the cloud forest and return to a pleasant suburb of Quito for a relaxing night at La Palma Polo Club

This morning, take the early flight to Baltra Island where your Galapagos adventure will begin onboard the beautiful midsize yacht, La Pinta. Launch straight into your adventure with a short hike with your resident biologists on South Plaza island. This stunning island offers a perfect introduction to the unique natural wonders of the Galapagos archipelago.

Explore Santa Fe Island, part of the “Humboldt quartet” of islands in the Galapagos. It’s a hotspot for genetic diversity and home to unique species like the Galapagos hawk and the elusive Santa Fe land iguana. Enjoy kayaking, snorkeling, and coastal exploration in the morning for a memorable visit. After a fulfilling lunch, we visited Puerto Baquerizo Moreno, where Charles Darwin first set foot in the Galapagos Islands. We then drove to Cerro, Colorado, to see the breeding center for giant tortoises in a captivating deciduous forest.

After arriving at Punta Pitt on the eastern tip of San Cristobal Island, you can enjoy a coastal trail with views of frigates and sea lions. Look out for various species of boobies. After, you can take a panga ride or go snorkeling to explore the marine life further.

Explore Punta Suarez in the morning to see unique lava terrain and remarkable seabird colonies. Keep an eye out for waved albatrosses, boobies, swallow-tail gulls, and the stunning “blowhole” lava formation against the backdrop of the Humboldt Current. Look for colorful marine iguanas. This visit promises unforgettable encounters. In the afternoon, we’ll visit Gardner Bay’s pristine white coral beach. Here, you can observe playful sea lions, graceful mockingbirds, and charming finches or enjoy snorkeling, kayaking, or a glass-bottom boat ride to explore marine life.

Depart the yacht this morning. We visit the Charles Darwin Research Station and its giant tortoise captive-rearing program, then transfer to Finch Bay hotel. Afternoon at leisure to explore the town or relax at the hotel.
Board the hotel's day charter yacht to visit nearby islands and encounter more of the amazing Galapagos residents not already sen.

HALF-DAY TORTUGA BAY A stunning adventure… Embark on a half-day journey and immerse in the breathtaking beauty of Tortuga Bay, renowned for its pristine white sands and crystal-clear waters. Begin your adventure with a scenic walk along a picturesque trail leading to this stunning beach, where the sands feel as soft as talcum powder beneath your feet, contrasting beautifully with the deep turquoise of the sea. As you arrive at the beach, marvel at the captivating views of Playa Brava, famous for its powerful waves and as a habitat for iconic Galapagos wildlife. Keep an eye out for sightings of herons, marine iguanas, and playful sea lions basking in the sun along the shoreline. Take a leisurely stroll to Playa Mansa, a serene bay with calm waters perfect for swimming, kayaking, and snorkeling. Here, you can observe marine species such as iguanas, sharks, turtles, and rays from the comfort of the shore. Spend your morning or afternoon exploring the wonders of Tortuga Bay, where every step reveals a new vista of natural splendor and adventure.
This morning, take a flight back to Quito and spend the evening at a historic hacienda, where you can indulge in a massage or wander the hotel's pitcturesque gardens
Depart from Quito Airport this morning

generalInfo:
Join us aboard a brand-new luxury yacht to discover the fascinating diversity of animal, marine and plant life on the western and central islands of the Galapagos. Expect stunning scenery, unforgettable wildlife and ultimate comfort as you visit famous islands such as Isabela Island, Floreana Island and Santa Cruz Island to name just a few. With snorkelling opportunities throughout, a dedicated expert guide and all excursions included, including a visit to the Charles Darwin Research Station, this is the most relaxing and unforgettable way to discover this remarkable archipelago.

This fantastic tour consists of an 8-day Galapagos cruise, with an overnight stay in Quito before and after the cruise.

dayInfo.description: Quito: Arrive at any time. Meet fellow travellers this evening at trip briefing. Overnight hotel stay included.

Baltra & Santa Cruz: Fly from Quito to Baltra before heading off on a highlands and wild tortoise excursion. You will get to see these giant reptiles, the Galapagos’ most famous residents, in their natural habitat of the Scalesia Forests. There will also be great birding opportunities here with us looking out for vermilion flycatchers and Darwin’s finches including the famous Woodpecker Finch. The afternoon will be spent at the Fausto Llerena Breeding Center and Charles Darwin Research Station before making the way to dinner aboard our luxury yacht.

Floreana Island: Landing at Punta Cormorant in the morning to enjoy guided walks and to discover two amazingly different beaches. Accompanied by your expert Naturalist you will learn all about the wildlife and natural history of the area and can enjoy a hike to a salt-water lagoon which is home to flamingos. You will also have the chance for your first snorkelling excursion as you explore under the waters of Champion Islet, considered one of the most beautiful places in all of the Galapagos for snorkelling. After lunch on board it will be time to go back to land again as we land on the beach of the famous Post Office Bay to see, and maybe even use, their iconic barrel mailbox, before making our way to Asilo de la Paz to explore a lava cave inhabited by ancient pirates, sightings of tortoises and enjoy unforgettable views from the top of the hill.

Isabela Island: We now make our way to Isabela Island to attempt a dry landing at Punta Moreno to see the lava formations and crystal tide pools that have formed in the craters created by lava flows from the three most active volcanoes in the archipelago. Surrounded by beautiful landscapes we will search these pools for sightings of marine wildlife including sea turtles and white-tip reef sharks, and the surrounding areas for birdlife including common gallinules, Galapagos doves, white-cheeked pintails and more pink flamingos. In the afternoon we will head to Elizabeth Bay for a thoroughly enjoyable Panga/Zodicac boat cruise through the mangroves in search of sightings of more wildlife including penguins, the iconic blue-footed boobies, pelicans, flightless cormorants, rays, marine turtles and much more.

Isabela & Fernandina Islands: Staying around Isabela Island, this morning we will land at Urbina Bay at the base of Alcedo Volcano to see the area’s fascinating geological formations and stunning volcano views, and search for sightings of sea turtles, stingrays and land and marine iguanas. In the afternoon we will sail over to Fernandina Island to land at Punta Espinoza to enjoy some fantastic walking trails across the lava flows that will lead us to some of the archipelago’s largest colonies of marine iguanas and sea birds, as well as good numbers of sea lions and a flightless cormorant nesting site. We also have good chances of seeing the Galapagos hawk here and for the snorkellers among us this is likely to be one of the most memorable areas for up-close marine life sightings.

Tagus Cove: Back on Isabela Island this morning you can take an enjoyable hike in Tagus Cove that will reward in some stunning views of Darwin Lake, the Darwin and Wolf volcanoes and the bay, whilst learning about the whalers and pirates that used to frequent here as you walk. You could also choose to explore the area by dinghy, join a kayaking excursion or snorkel with schools of tropical fish and look for sharks, seahorses and rockfish. In the afternoon you can explore by land or underwater around the two coves of Punta Vicente Roca on the lookout for penguins, sea lions, Nazca and blue-footed boobies, puffer fish, rays and sea turtles.

Santiago Island: Today we will move on to Santiago Island with our first stop being Buccaneer Cove to see its towering cliff wall rock formations that are home to hundreds of seabirds. This is also another great spot for snorkelling. In the afternoon we will move on to Puerto Egas, also known as James Bay, for more snorkelling opportunities and the chance to follow some gorgeous trails along the coastline to see grottos full of fauna including Galapagos fur sea lions and an abundance of reptiles and shore birds.

Las Bachas & Cerro Dragon: Visit Bachas Beach in the morning, located on the northeastern tip of Santa Cruz Island. A great beach to stroll on with crystalline waters perfect for swimming, Bachas Beach also gives visitors the opportunity to see frigatebirds, blue-footed boobies, and sea lions. In the afternoon, visit Cerro Dragón, on the west coast of Santa Cruz Island. See land iguanas as well as a saltwater lagoon frequented by flamingos and various species of birds.
Having enjoyed our last night on board, on the morning of day 9 we will disembark in Baltra and fly back to Quito for one final night on the Ecuadorian mainland.

generalInfo:
Machu Picchu and the Galapagos are rightly two of South America's highlights and regularly exceed expectations. This itinerary is designed for those who wish to see both of these highlights but may be restricted to just two weeks travel time.

You'll begin in Cuzco. As the capital of the vast Inca empire and their ‘navel of the world’, Cuzco was a remarkable city, reputedly built in the shape of a puma, full of magnificent stone palaces and temples decorated with gold. Modern-day Cuzco is a proud, beautiful and lively city with a vibrant art scene, excellent museums and fine restaurants.

Next, make your way through the Sacred Valley. This winding and fertile valley between Pisac and Ollantaytambo was at the spiritual and commercial heart of the Inca empire. There are numerous ways to explore this region whether by taking it in on foot or visiting the people who have called this area home for centuries.

At last you will reach the crown jewel of the Inca Empire, Machu Picchu. Aside from a few llamas grazing the grassy terraces, and a viscacha (a rabbit-like rodent) or two snuggling in the empty window holes, the ruins are unadorned and devoid of any living presence (other than humans of course, all the relics found there are displayed in a museum in Cuzco). Arrive there in the early morning, and you’ll see how the morning cloud gradually disperses into wisps, revealing the buildings and terracing layer by layer.

When you're time delving into Peru's past concludes you will switch gears and begin making your way towards the wildlife Eden that is the Galapagos. The Galapagos Islands' reputation as one of the world's most magnificent nature and wildlife experiences is wholly justified. You will explore the archipelago on board a small ship cruise, taking trips out to various islands and being guided by an expert naturalist guide. We can discuss the islands to visit in more detail when we work on your itinerary. Whichever you choose, you won’t be short of flora and fauna, highlights including marine iguanas, the Galapagos tortoise, frigatebirds and maybe even whales and dolphins.

dayInfo.description: On arrival in Lima you will connect with your flight to Cuzco where you will be met and transferred to your hotel.
Enjoy a guided tour of the highlights of Cuzco and the surrounding Inca ruins.
Full day trip to the Sacred Valley of the Incas. You will visit the impressive ruins at Pisac and Ollantaytambo as well as a vibrant market. Overnight in the Sacred Valley.
Take the train to Machu Picchu, where you will have a guided tour of the ancient Inca citadel.
Free day to explore Machu Picchu at your own pace. In the afternoon return to Cuzco by train.
Transfer to the airport in time for your flight to Quito via Lima. Upon arrival you will be met and taken to your hotel.
Enjoy a guided tour of Quito, a UNESCO World Heritage Site

Transfer to the airport in time for your flight to the Galapagos Islands. Here you will be met by a representative of your boat who will take you to your awaiting vessels. Afternoon excursions in the Galapagos.
Excursions from the boat with your naturalist guide
Excursions from the boat with your naturalist guide
Excursions from the boat with your naturalist guide
Excursions in the Galapagos Islands followed by disembarkation and flight back to the Ecuadorian mainland.

tourName: Mainland Ecuador holiday, culture, nature & adventure
placesVisited: Quito, Ecuadorian cookery class, Cloud forest walks, Bird watching, Hike and swim at waterfall, Cotopaxi National Park, Mountain trekking, Horseback tour, Devil’s Nose train ride, Ingapirca ruins, Cuenca, Spa, Cajas National Park
generalInfo:
This 11 day tour combines some of Ecuador’s most stunning landscapes with cities and culture. With its mix of hiking, scenic train rides, horse riding and sightseeing tours, it’s the perfect way to discover this diverse country, from wildlife-filled cloud forest and the breath-taking Andes, to the Pacific Coast.

We will visit two of the most important cities in Ecuador during this tour which are Quito and Cuenca. Both beautiful, historical cities boast a wealth of UNESCO World Heritage Sites, attractive architecture and dramatic, mountainous settings. As well as exploring the streets, you’ll learn how to cook local dishes with a cookery class and have the chance to unwind at a natural hot spring spa. We’ll also spend some time in the port city of Guayaquil, where beaches and tasty seafood await.

We’ll spend two days exploring Ecuador’s cloud forest, staying for two nights in a lodge. During that time, we’ll watch out for spectacled bears while hiking the forest trails, experience a dawn chorus and go bird watching, followed by a dip in a waterfall or swimming hole. There will also be the chance to see more iconic South American wildlife, such as coati and condors, in Cajas National Park.

Ecuador is home to 47 volcanoes, and we’ll visit three of the most famous: Cotopaxi, Rumiñahui and Chimborazo. We’ll also drive through the impressively scenic Volcano Avenue, go horseback riding in Cotopaxi National Park and maybe kayak on Quilotoa Loop, a spectacular crater lake, before taking a ride on the Devil’s Nose train and visiting the Ingapirca ruins.

dayInfo.description: AIRPORT PICKUP – TRANSFER TO HOTEL Your Hidden Treasures Ecuador tour starts here. You will be picked up at the Mariscal Sucre International Airport (UIO) and brought to your hotel, which is located in the center of Quito. Depending on the time of arrival at the airport, you will have the chance to explore Quito by yourself and taste the local dishes and drinks. Of course, it is also possible to rest because you might be tired after a long flight.

HISTORICAL CENTER – COOKING CLASS – CAPILLA DEL HOMBRE (B, L) After breakfast in the hotel you will go to the Historical Center of Quito to explore the many UNESCO World Heritage Sites. After getting an impression of this beautiful city, you will get a cooking class where you learn how to cook local dishes. In the afternoon you will visit the Capilla del Hombre where you have an amazing view over the city. (All transportation is included). Accommodation in Hotel Ikala Quito or similar

INTIÑAN MUSEUM – PULULAHUA – CLOUD FOREST (B, L, D) In the morning we will first visit the Intiñan museum and go to the Pululahua volcano. After that you will be transferred to a beautiful place in the Cloud Forest. Before lunch you will take a guided short walk to learn about some of Maquipucuna’s medicinal and useful plants. After lunch you will walk through the Bear trail and part of the Palmito or River trails in search of spectacled bears or their traces. This is a moderate hike (2 to 3 hours) through Secondary and some Primary Forest. A local guide is mandatory during Spectacled Bear season. At 6pm the bar opens officially; however, if you desire a drink before then, please let the staff know and they will be happy to serve you. There is also the chance to do an optional guided night hike. Accommodation in Maquipucuna Reserve Lodge or similar

BIRD WATCHING – HIKE TO WATERFALL / SELF GUIDED WALK (B, L, D) Wake up with a concert of birds and get ready for an early start. After enjoying a cup of our own freshly brewed coffee, you have the first birding hike from 6:30 – 8:30 AM to enjoy the sounds and sights of dawn in the forest. Before lunch you will take the Humedal trail learning further about plants and watching birds as we progress into the the pre-Inca trail used by the Yumbos. As a reward, you will reach the Yumbo waterfall or swimming hole where you will have the opportunity to take a swim. After lunch you will visit the coffee orchard, the orchid garden and the organic garden. Alternatively after breakfast, you could take a half day or full day tour to the Ziplines, Tulipe archeological site or Mindo butterfly garden. You can also do an optional guided night hike. Accommodation in Maquipucuna Reserve Lodge or similar

COTOPAXI – HORSEBACK RIDING (B, L) After breakfast you will drive to the Cotopaxi Volcano area, which takes about 4 hours to get there. You will start your tour with a very nice car ride from Quito through the Volcano Avenue; including the Pasochoa, Rumiñahui, Illinizas and others. When you arrive there you will have a lunch and after that you will do a horseback riding tour in the slopes of the Rumiñahui Volcano. Accommodation in Hacienda El Porvenir or similar

COTOPAXI NATIONAL PARK – LIMPIOPUNGO LAGOON – INSILIVI (B, L, D) When you finish your breakfast in the morning, you will visit the Cotopaxi National Park and the Limpiopungo Lagoon. After that, you will depart to Isinliví and there you will have lunch. In the afternoon you will go for a trekking exploration around the Isinliví mountains. In the evening you will have a nice local dinner.

QUILOTOA – TIGUA – GUAMOTE – CHIMBORAZO (B ,D) In the morning you will visit the Quilotoa Loop, and have the chance to hike down and actually feel the temperature of the lake, when time allows it you can even kayak on the lake. After that you will go to Tigua, where you will visit the local community. In the afternoon you will drive to Guamote, on your way there you have the chance to make some amazing photos of the Chimborazo volcano. Accommodation in Inti Sisa or similar

GUAMOTE – DEVILS NOSE – INGAPIRCA – CUENCA (B) Around 08.00 AM you will go on the Devil’s Nose train ride. You will learn about one of the greatest rail engineering feats worldwide while passing through the beautiful Andean scenery. In the afternoon you will visit the Ingapirca ruins after which you will be transferred to your hotel in Cuenca. Accommodation in Hotel Victoria or similar

CUENCA CITY TOUR – SPA CIRCUIT (B) Today, you will have a very relaxing day. This is your time to explore one of the most beautiful cities in Ecuador. Cuenca won South America’s Leading City Break Destination of 2018, and you will see in this tour why that is the case. It is an amazing city with a lot of UNESCO World Heritage Sites. You will start this day with a city tour around Cuenca, and after that, you will visit Piedra de Agua hot springs, a nice spot where you will get the chance to relax and unwind by doing a Spa Circuit. Accommodation in Hotel Victoria or similar

CUENCA – CAJAS – GUAYAQUIL (B) After breakfast at the hotel, you will spend a half day at Cajas National Park. In this park you will spot many beautiful lakes. It is also home to many wild animals such as Andean condors, giant hummingbirds and coatis. After exploring the great wildlife and nature, you will continue to Guayaquil where you will enjoy the city by night and enjoy its beautiful panoramic views. You will visit the most beautiful areas and buildings of Guayaquil. Accommodation in Wyndham Guayaquil or similar

TRANSFER OUT (B) This is your last day of your Hidden Treasures Ecuador tour. Depending on the time of your flight, you will be brought to the airport. Any time of the day is fine to get your flight out, we will arrange a transfer to the airport for you. End of services.

placesVisited: Lima, Cusco, Sacred Valley of the Incas, Pisac complex & Ollantaytambo, Machu Picchu by rail, Lake Titicaca, Uros Islands Sillustani, Guyaquil, Four-day Galápagos Islands cruise on a motor yacht, Optional: walk a section of the Inca Trail, climb Huayna Picchu
generalInfo:
Taking a two week holiday to South America can feel like a compromise; how do you choose between its phenomenal wealth of cultural and natural highlights, without feeling like you’ve missed out? This small group, Peru and Galapagos holiday is one solution – giving you plenty of time to explore the Incan wonders of Peru before flying 1,000km offshore to the Galapagos Islands, to encounter volcanic landscapes and a wealth of wildlife. Your tour leader will take care of all the logistics, with specialist guides joining you along the way to share the secrets of Peru and Ecuador’s most impressive cultural and natural highlights.

Internal flights ensure you cover more ground in less time, as you are whisked down to Cuzco from Lima, to start your trip at the heart of the Inca Empire. Here, immaculately crafted stone walls stand side by side with baroque colonial churches and contemporary bars and cafes – a wonderful insight into ancient and modern Andean culture. Travel deeper into the mountains and further back in time with explorations of ruins such as Pisac and Sacsayhuamán – taking the train to Machu Picchu for the grand finale. From here you’ll venture down to Lake Titicaca, ringed by snowy Andean peaks, and where you can take a tour to the floating Uros Islands, woven from reeds.

The next set of islands have somewhat more solid foundations: the volcanic Galapagos, reached via a flight from Lima via Guayaquil in Ecuador. You’ll have five days to explore this fascinating archipelago while living onboard a comfortable motor yacht with en suite cabins. Embark each day to discover how Darwin developed his theory of evolution and see how the giant tortoises, marine iguanas and dancing boobies have adapted to life in this remote outpost.

dayInfo.title: Overnight in the capital.
dayInfo.description: Those passengers arriving on an international flight will be met at the airport by the tour leader or a local representative who will escort you to the hotel. The scenes from your window on the half-hour drive to the hotel through Lima encapsulate the invigorating bustle of a modern-day Latin American capital. Lima, the City of Kings, was once the capital of Spanish America, and the vestiges of its glorious past can still be seen in the faded grandeur of the colonial churches and traditional wooden balconies in the city centre. The explosive growth of the last 50 years, so typical of capital cities in the developing world, has transformed Lima into a dynamic and chaotic low-rise city of over 10 million people. In crowded streets, throngs of traffic race out towards Miraflores, a modern middle-class suburb on the coast, where your hotel is located. You’ll have time to explore in more depth on the final day of the Peruvian leg of your trip.

dayInfo.title: Fly to the Inca capital of Cusco.
dayInfo.description: A flight of just an hour takes you to Cusco. The name Cusco derives from the Quechua word for navel, indicating its location at the centre of the Inca Empire, which reached its zenith at the same time as England was fighting the War of the Roses. Today its many impressive original Inca walls display extraordinary craftsmanship, while the bustling squares are dotted with ornate baroque colonial churches. It’s a vivacious city, where shoeshine boys and postcard sellers jostle for your attention in cobbled streets lined with handicraft shops and cafés. In the evening, the town centre fills with people flocking to the many restaurants, bars and cafés.

dayInfo.title: Tour of Cusco and nearby archaeological sites.
dayInfo.description: Today an experienced guide gives you a half day tour of the city. You visit Q’oricancha, once the principal Inca Sun Temple, with extraordinarily intricate stonework, and then explore the colossal zigzag walls of Sacsayhuamán, brooding on a hillside above Cusco. In 1536 a desperate and defining three-day battle was fought between the Spaniards and the Incas around this fortress. The first conquistadors to see it were awestruck, and centuries later it is still an extraordinary and imposing sight. There is also free time to explore Cusco; to wander through its cobbled streets bracketed by impressive Inca walls, to explore its colourful, bustling markets and splendid churches, and to stop at some of the many excellent cafés.

dayInfo.title: Excursion to the Sacred Valley of the Incas; overnight.
dayInfo.description: Today, head out from Cusco over the high plains and descend to explore the fertile Sacred Valley of the Incas. Once the bread-basket of the Inca Empire, it was heavily populated in imperial times and scores of archaeological sites remain, where well-preserved ruins bear witness to the highly developed society that the Incas created. The drive passes through or close to several of the villages and temple fortresses which pepper the valley. The Pisac complex, set high above and visible from the eponymous colonial village you will visit, is built on terraces carved into the steep hillsides. The engineering and preservation are unrivalled. From the flat valley floor this intricate hillside rises up like a green staircase to the heavens. Continue along this picturesque, patchwork valley to the temple of Ollantaytambo. The snow-frosted Andean cordillera forms a stunning backdrop. Ollantaytambo, sitting strategically at the gateway to the Amazon basin, was never captured by the Spanish conquistadors, but the inhabitants decided that the settlement was too vulnerable and would eventually fail, and so they abandoned it. The fortress, the colonial grid plan and the Inca foundations are still intact and there are wonderful views down over the sloping hillsides and into the fertile valley. Spend the night in the tranquil valley.

dayInfo.title: By rail to Machu Picchu.
dayInfo.description: Travelling for just 2hrs by train from Ollantaytambo, you reach the ruins of Machu Picchu. As the river Urubamba enters its narrow gorge between thickly-forested granite hills, there is room only for a single track, which hugs the right bank and passes through hamlets that are no more than a collection of shacks beside the railway. Close to the foot of the mountain on a saddle of which the citadel was built is the bustling village of Machu Picchu (formerly known as Aguas Calientes), dedicated to serving the many visitors with artisan markets, bars and restaurants. The majestic ruined city, reclaimed from tropical cloud forest, is reached by minibus up a sinuous road, or on foot up a near vertical rocky path. The American explorer Hiram Bingham discovered it in 1911, by which time it was completely buried beneath jungle vegetation. It is perhaps the ruins’ location, on a ridge spur amid forested peaks and above a roaring river canyon, that most ignites the imagination. You will have a guided tour of the ruins. Fancy hiking some of the Inca Trail without interrupting your tour? We can organise for you to walk the mini Inca Trail on this day, but still, have a guided tour of the ruins and stay with the group in the evening. Please ask us for more details.

dayInfo.title: Optional re-entry to ruins; return to Cusco by rail and road.
dayInfo.description: There is the option to return to the ruins with time to walk one of the many trails within the site itself, such as the hike to the vertiginous Inca Bridge, carved into a cliff edge. You can climb the tortuously steep Huayna Picchu mountain on the other side of the valley (please enquire with the office, as spaces are limited and it’s necessary to pre-book). Your tour leader will be on hand to talk through the various walking options. In the afternoon return to Cusco, arriving in the early evening.

dayInfo.title: Private road journey to Lake Titicaca.
dayInfo.description: Travel by coach from Cusco to Puno, on Lake Titicaca, a spectacular 8 hr journey (including stops) which climbs to over 4,300m. Flanked by snow-capped peaks, the lonely road cuts its way through fields worked by men and oxen; an Andean landscape of adobe huts, and crops of corn and potato. After reaching the highest point of the journey, the bus crosses the altiplano, a large, windswept plain punctuated by occasional market towns, where bowler-hatted women tend their herds of llamas and alpacas. The vast, indigo Lake Titicaca – almost an inland sea – sits on the Peruvian-Bolivian border, and the fish-laden waters and surrounding fertile soil are the lifeblood of the subsistence farming communities clustered in scores of adobe villages along the water’s edge. Legend has it that this mystical spot is the birthplace of Inca civilisation: the progeny of the Sun God emerged from its depths to found the empire in Cusco.

dayInfo.title: Boat trip to the Uros Islands and tour of Sillustani.
dayInfo.description: Today you set out on the lake aboard a motor boat to visit the Uros Islands: gliding over the deep glacial waters on a sunny day is a definite highlight. You alight on the floating islands, constructed entirely from the lake’s tortora reeds – the same material used to build their canoes – and the ground moves almost imperceptibly beneath your feet. During severe storms, the islands may break up into smaller islets. Once devoted to fishing, the inhabitants now earn their living mainly through selling handicrafts to tourists and, while this is a unique experience, it has the air of a living museum. In the afternoon, there’s a guided excursion to the Chullpas at Sillustani, towering stone tombs said to be the burial site of the ancient Hatun Colla chiefs. The towers are on the treeless shores of a lonely highland lake; the landscape, while unremittingly bleak, is spellbinding.

dayInfo.title: Fly back to Lima.
dayInfo.description: Take the morning flight to Lima (2 hours) where there is an optional tour of the colonial centre of the city, including the central Plaza de Armas, which is surrounded by beautiful colonial and republican buildings. There may be time to visit one of the world famous museums. That evening, from Miraflores, you can sit with a pisco sour cocktail and watch the sun set over the Pacific, and contemplate the next phase of your adventure.

dayInfo.title: Fly to Guayaquil; guided city tour.
dayInfo.description: You say goodbye to your Journey Latin America tour leader, who will take you to the airport for a morning flight to Guayaquil (2 hours). Ecuador’s largest city is situated on the banks of the Río Guayas, and has gone through something of a transition in the last few years. The expanse of waterfront has been made into an outdoor architectural showpiece, and restoration work has taken place along the city’s main thoroughfare and in the historical neighbourhood of Las Peñas. A city tour will take you from the frenetic open-air market at La Bahia, and past the colonial naval shipyard to the Malecón (the waterfront promenade), Guayaquil’s crowning jewel. Stroll past tropical gardens, bustling markets and cafés, and head to Santa Ana Hill and Las Peñas, a district of brightly-coloured wooden houses and ramshackle streets dating back to the 16th century. The local guide will accompany you to dinner (not included) before dropping you back at the hotel.

dayInfo.title: Fly to the Galápagos Islands
dayInfo.description: Transfer to the airport for your flight to the Galápagos Islands (2 hrs) where you will embark on the motor yacht for your 5 day cruise around the archipelago. Once you’ve paid your national park entrance fee, your naturalist guide will be waiting to take you to the quayside. The Galápagos Islands emerged in the Pacific Ocean six million years ago following a spate of volcanic activity and, isolated from the continental mainland, have become home to unique animal and plant species. The islands were the inspiration for Charles Darwin’s theory of evolution, which formed the basis for his revolutionary book ‘The Origin of the Species’, published in 1859. Without fear of humans, they are sufficiently trusting to allow you to approach them and observe them up close. Although geologically constantly on the move, these islands remain suspended in time, with a wealth of rare fauna and flora all thriving there. For many, the fascinating and unique wildlife and natural beauty of the islands are matched by the thrill of being at sea. Find a spot on deck as you make your way through the ocean, often trailed by flocks of birds and playful dolphins. The boats are relatively small, creating an informal atmosphere. The service is of high quality; the crew are attentive and the food delicious. Cabins with en suite facilities are compact but comfortable for your 4 nights on board. There is a common bar/lounge area as well as a sun deck. Beach towels are provided, and basic snorkelling equipment is available and wetsuits can be hired.

dayInfo.title: Cruise through the archipelago.
dayInfo.description: The itinerary for your cruise is subject to change due to National Park rules. There are normally two landings a day to seek out the different wildlife that inhabits the islands. Below is a summary of the animals and birds that can be found on each of the islands that you visit on this journey. There will also be the opportunity to snorkel both from the islands and the boat itself, and 2 kayaks are also available for use by passengers. Bartolomé Island is a small, uninhabited islet in the Galápagos, known for its striking volcanic landscape and the iconic Pinnacle Rock. Visitors enjoy panoramic views, encounters with penguins and sea lions, and excellent snorkelling in clear, wildlife-rich waters. North Seymour Island is a flat, rocky island in the Galápagos, known for its abundant wildlife and vibrant bird colonies. Visitors can observe blue-footed boobies, frigatebirds, and land iguanas up close, along with sea lions and marine iguanas along the coast. Mosquera Islet is a small, sandy islet located between Baltra and North Seymour in the Galápagos Islands. It’s a great spot to observe sea lions, shorebirds, and occasional lava gulls. Genovesa Island is a remote and wildlife-rich destination in the northern Galápagos. Formed from a volcanic caldera, it features dramatic cliffs, a sunken crater bay, and two main visitor sites—Prince Philip’s Steps and Darwin Bay. The island is a haven for birdwatchers, with large colonies of red-footed boobies, Nazca boobies, frigatebirds, and storm petrels. South Plaza Island is a small but ecologically rich islet off the eastern coast of Santa Cruz in the Galápagos. It’s home to large colonies of land iguanas, sea lions, and nesting swallow-tailed gulls. Santa Fe Island is one of the oldest islands in the Galápagos, known for its scenic bay, turquoise waters, and unique wildlife. It’s home to the Santa Fe land iguana, found nowhere else. Also visit the David Rodriguez Tortoise Centre in San Cristobal at the end of your trip. For 2027 the islands visited will remain largely the same but please speak to one of our travel consultants for details.

dayInfo.title: Fly to Guayaquil and continue to your international flight or extension.
dayInfo.description: After disembarking you fly back to Guayaquil (1.5 hours) and continue to your international flight or extension. If you would like to break your return journey back to the UK a night in Guayaquil after your cruise can easily be arranged. Please speak to one of our consultants for the extra cost involved).

placesVisited: Lima, Amazon rainforest, Sacred Valley, Machu Picchu, Cusco, Quito, Mindo Cloud Forest, Andes adventures, Galapagos Islands, private city tours, jungle lodge, kayaking, hiking or mountain biking in the Andes, ziplining, canopy walks, river tubing or nature walks in the Cloud Forest
generalInfo:
If you’re going to see South America, why not see multiple countries? Neighbours Peru and Ecuador present an Andean feast of culture and landscapes, and you can spend some time on the Galapagos Islands afterwards.

This trip is so adventurous, it takes you into the Andes twice – once in search of Machu Picchu, and again for trekking around Cotopaxi or Otavalo. In these dramatic landscapes – cloud forests, high mountain, lush valleys, you’ll find plenty of opportunities for fun activities – such as mountain biking, horse riding, trekking and ziplining.

After arriving in Lima, Peru you go straight into the Amazon for three days in a jungle lodge, from which you can venture out on foot and by canoe, in search of wildlife. From here you transfer to the Sacred Valley where you’ll spend a day with the Misminay Community, learning about their traditional crafts and practices, before perhaps a spot of mountain biking in the surrounding mountains. You can’t visit the Sacred Valley without seeing Machu Picchu, and you’ll get a day exploring – the ruins of this Inca city have one of the most stunning settings in the world. After a day in Cusco, it’s time to cross over to Ecuador.

Your introduction to Ecuador starts with its capital, Quito, but before long you’re off out in nature again, this time in the Mindo cloud forests. Ecuador also has its fair share of the Andes, and so you can decide whether you want to trek near Cotopaxi, the snow-capped volcano, or visit the town of Otovalo in the mountains, a place where the main draw is the market, which is full of beautiful crafts made by the Otovalo people.

From mainland Ecuador it’s a short flight to the Galapagos Islands. Famous for their amazing nature encounters, these islands can be explored in many ways, depending on your interest – whether by cruise, island hopping or beach hotel, you’ll be able to experience unforgettable wildlife in near-pristine settings.

This holiday focuses on connecting you to the communities that you visit – whether spending a day with Indigenous Peoples in the Sacred Valley, or spending time among craftspeople in Otovalo, this trip focuses your money directly into local areas, where it will protect the land and traditions – hopefully for many visits to come.

dayInfo.description: LIMA - Start your epic journey in the buzzing capital of Peru, where you can choose between a classic historical city tour, a bike tour, or a cultural tour of street art and local eateries.

AMAZON - After a short flight, transfer by boat to your comfortable jungle lodge for days of wildlife spotting and jungle adventure by foot and canoe. Expect to see monkeys, caiman, turtles, parrots, and hundreds of other species.

SACRED VALLEY - We move to the cultural heart of both ancient Inca and modern rural Peru, with an extended stay in the magnificent Sacred Valley. Spend a day with the welcoming Mismimay Community, taking part in their traditional cooking, weaving, and agricultural pastimes. Visit the must-see sights of Ollantaytambo, with a special Pachamanca lunch, and choose from kayaking, hiking, or mountain biking against the Andes backdrop on your third day here.

MACHU PICCHU & CUSCO - Next up is a visit to one of the Manmade Wonders Of The World, the iconic Inca citadel of Machu Picchu. After a day exploring the impressive site, we take the train to Cusco and wander the ancient streets, modern galleries and thriving food scene.

QUITO - Part 2 of your journey takes you to Ecuador, starting with the charming capital Quito. Take a walking tour of the UNESCO-listed colonial centre, with optional cultural activities ranging from chocolate tasting to artist visits.

CLOUD FOREST - Just 2 hours from Quito is the bird-watchers paradise of Mindo, a steamy cloud forest with an incredible diversity of flora and fauna. From your rustic lodge here you can also try ziplining, canopy walks, river tubing, and of course nature walks amongst the lush forest.

COTOPAXI OR OTAVALO - Up into the Andes again, choose between the indigenous region of Otavalo for craft markets and traditional weavers, or Cotopaxi for it's snow-capped volcano. Both areas offer stunning trekking opportunities past waterfalls and crater lakes, horse-riding and mountain biking under the gaze of volcanoes.

GALAPAGOS - We end this magical adventure in the wildlife wonderland of the Galapagos Islands.
